ReviewList.Text: This was a decent book. A good summer read for the beach. Lite and fun. However, I went into it thinking it was a book for adults which I suppose it is supposed to be. However, I wonder is this a book for adults that read teen literature? I would have no qualms about giving this to my eleven year old son to read. Except for a very few "bad" words, there's really nothing to be offended by here. Fairly bloodless violence, no sex. But I didn't find this in the teen literature section which is what kind of aggravates me. Yet it seems like teen literature. Yet I don't think most teens would get a lot of the references. I guess I'm a little unclear about who this book is for. People that don't want to grow up or people that have yet to grow up.

Okay if you like 70s D&D; and Rush and 80s video games and pop culture, this book is your crack. This is a really good book! I don't know if I can give a 100% spoiler free review so read at your own risk: there is a huge puzzle in a virtual reality world with the whole world as the prize, and to crack the code the people and corporations of the future are immersing themselves in the singular creator's passions, which are all completely retro - Dungeons and Dragons, Trash 80 text only games, 80s movies, etc. I liked the CHARACTERS even if they were broadly drawn. I liked the bad guys, they always surprised me with how evil they could get while very much resembling the constantly-excused corporate overlords of today. The near future world of energy crisis and indentured servitude to corporations for unpaid debts was one of my favorite parts of the book. And while you're reading, it'll all fly by and you'll love every word. Until after the book. The biggest problem I have is this massive puzzle, built by a genius, which took five years to get a crack in the armor, then devolved into a fairly 'easy' scavenger hunt. I guessed at the first clue for the first key before the main character did. I like books where I am amazed at how smart the author is and he's always 10 steps ahead of me, but I didn't feel like that with the puzzle aspect of this book. That is a quibble, nitpicking for sure, because the experience of reading was great. 4 stars.

Being a child of the 80s, weaned on TRS-80s, the HHG to the Galaxy, and Monty Python, I should have liked this book. Instead, the main character came off as boastful, cold, and shallow, constantly rattling off the 100s of hours he logged playing popular 80s video games and re-watching bad 80's movies. The nostalgia does not merit a plod through poor writing and unsympathetic characters.

While driving cross-country I listened to the audible version read by Wil Wheaton. First, Wheaton nailed the narration. It helps that the main character seems to match how Wheaton comes across on TWIT. Five stars for the narration!  The book itself is fun and the pace is good.  I read some review that said it was like DaVinci Code with a Cyberpunk theme and I think that is a good description--a fun book but not really great. It's definitely not in the league of Snow Crash or any book by Stephenson, Gibson, etc. Much of the plot movement involves pulling an arbitrary rabbit out of a hat. Wade gets stuck in some way and instead of tying threads together through the story, some random solution is presented. The characters and the world itself are 2D and not described in much detail. For example, the story takes place in a post peak-oil world, but that world is only briefly described. Don't get me wrong, I enjoyed reading the book, but I wouldn't describe it as great.

Plunges into nerd detail immediately (including footnotes!) There's no need to read this or the thousand other adoring reviews to recognize the electricity at the page 6 footnote: "A freeze-frame of this scene appears nearly identical to a painting by Jeff Easley that appeared on the cover of the Dungeon's Master's Guide...". If that gave you the same thrill as it gave me then: (a) you are a nerd, and (b) you will love this book. The book's preview is available on the (Paperback) page, and is a very fair representation of what you're getting. The whole book is like that; the upfront nerd delight reminds me of 'Soon I Will be Invincible' page 1, but 'Ready Player One' differs from that book in defiantly embracing the values of an 80s video game: Cline isn't discussing or challenging these conventions; he is celebrating them, and he doesn't stop until the last page. If you are looking for classical literary merit, you've come to the wrong place. Reading it (in one sitting) I was disappointed by the aggressively simple-minded approach to character, plot, theme, etc., but if you love a book then it deserves five stars, and I loved every word. Yes, I would have preferred a more reflective or nuanced take on the material, but the writing keeps you hooked from page to page. Playing a great computer game, you're not asking for depth... you know the game is good when you skip sleep to play it. Judged in those terms, and judged in terms of commitment to its concept this is an A+ success. And its an A+ success that makes trenchant points too; it's just that its points are *about* nerdcore subjects (not literary ones) and in this it is hard-line & universally correct: permanent death *is* essential to making an RPG awesome.

This is a young adult book written for 40 year olds.  Character development is minimal, the plot is simple, and the reader isn't given much to ponder (the bad guys are obviously bad, the relationships are simple, the puzzles are quickly explained).  The cultural references are well-researched and I did enjoy reminiscing about movies, music, and video games.  It is a quick read and I enjoyed it while reading it.  It could make a good summer movie.

As a geek, a mother of 2 Gen-xers, and Trivia buff, Ready Player One was a rollicking good read. For me, it was as good as Hunger Games but with more fun factor. And gosh, I remember far too many of those games, systems, and 80's entertainment references than is probably healthy for one person. Nice tight little plot, believable geeks and online culture, requisite Big Bad...even 'The DeLorean' for good measure. I'm going to have to go back and re-read it slower this time to catch more references.

A strained premise, a derivative plot, two-dimensional characters, an entirely predictable finale --- yeah, I get it, 80s pop references, blah blah blah, but really, this book was a huge disappointment.

Ready Player One has one heck of a strong hook. The idea of the hunt for the late nerdy eccentric billionaire James Halliday's vast fortune in the form of a video game easter egg hunt across thousands of virtual worlds struck a loud chord with me and I was truly excited for the adventure I was about to embark on. I will sum up the main problem with this book in one word - conflict. There wasn't enough of it. It seemed that every time Wade entered a dangerous situation he would just ace it like it wasn't even a challenge. I get that he is supposed to be good at games because of all the practice he has had, but he really had very little trouble whenever a challenge presented itself. I enjoyed all the nods to old games, books and movies, but it got to the point where they felt like they were being mentioned just for the sake of being mentioned. Like I said, it had a great start out of the gate, but it wasn't able to hold up across the length of the book. Silly plot devices, flat characters, tired stereotypes(don't get me started on the characters from Japan), and heaps and heaps of info dumps to slog through. I finished it to the predictable end, but by then it felt like I was reading the script for a flimsy Saturday morning cartoon episode rather than well-thought out novel and I was glad I to be done with it. The first half of the book is great, truly, I just wish it could have held to that level for its entire length.

I don't want to say too much for fear of delving into the plot (besides, I think the other users and the book summary have that covered anyway) this book is a great read. First off, if you're into video games (of all kinds) and 80s film/pop culture, this will probably be your new favorite book. If you've every played a massively multiplayer online game you will have no problem understanding every aspect of the world, and it should be really easy for you to picture events as they unfold (as a gamer this definitely helped me enjoy the book). Most of the story takes place in an online "game" called the OASIS, however Cline ties the virtual world to reality at really crucial moments reminding you that the "game" the characters are playing might be more serious than fun. Cline's personality comes through heavily into his writing. Much of the writing is clever, the ideas and fiction are extremely interesting to read about, and its an easy read. Some of Cline's writing style however may allow too much sidebar or too much explanation, which at times detracts from the story. Overall, the adventure that unfolds in Ready Player One is enjoyable, exciting, and a little quirky, but ultimately just really, really cool.

I enjoyed reading this book since I'm a child of the 70's and 80's, had a Commodore 64, and played a lot of video games.  I loved all of the pop culture references from the time and had fun reliving my childhood and teenage years.  The book also has some interesting ideas and overall "puzzle" for the protagonist to complete.  My main problem with it is that the dialog seems like it was written by a teenager rather than a 40 year old writer.  It's as is if this novel was targeted to the young adult readership except it has way too many cuss words, inappropriate content, and most of the references in the book would be lost on today's teenagers.  So I don't really understand who the audience is for this book.  In the hands of a better writer this would have been a 5 star book.  Unfortunately the author spent very little time making his characters 3 dimensional and the dialogue for the most part is terrible.  But the overall plot and events in the book sort of make up for the lack of characterization and turned it into a fun read for me.  It's just too bad he didn't spend more time making his characters into believable 19 and 20 year olds instead of making them sound like 12 year old jerks.
I'm usually not a sci-fi fan at all but I could not put this book down. I just finished it and I almost want to pick it back up and start reading it all over again.

ever. Although I love to read, and do it often, I don't think i've ever taken the time to stop and write a review, until now. This book made me do it. I was immersed from the start. Being a child of the 80s myself this book spoke to me. I remember the Commodore 64, and Tandy computer, and arcades, and Colecovision, and atari 64. I remember the first time I played Super Mario Brothers in an arcade, and Double Dragon. I remember Legend and Labirynth and Back to the Future, and Sixteen Candles and Gremlins and Goonies and Aliens. And this book brought me back to all of that. I could imagine being a kid immersed in a world full of lore from a time of my life filled with so much joy and wonder and naivete of youth. This book grabbed me and made it so I hated to put it down. Now i'm mad I rushed to the end and didn't stop to take the time to enjoy more every remembrance of my childhood. This is a fantastic book, with a fantastic story and a predictable and still fantastic ending. Bravo Mr. Cline, Bravo. You have just gained a new fan.

Quintessential Geek Ernest Cline has woven a story that is almost beyond compare. A tail of nerdom, suspense, and love. Set in a mildly dystopian future, there is a hint of what the world could be - good and bad. Like a good cup a coffee, this debut novel is a fast paced read that is smooth on the digestion. The plot is easy to follow but not to obvious that I was not saying to myself "I know where this is going". There are may places in the book that seem semi-autobiographic. If you are a fan of gaming you will love this book. There is just enough gaming jargon and subculture terminology that non-gamers will not be lost. The 80's nostalgia is pleasant and made me put the book down a couple times and meditate on some of the things I remember of the that time. This tome made me laugh, cry, and reminisce. I believe this is not the last we will see of Cline and this universe he has woven for the masses.

This is by far one of the best books I have read this year, I listened to the audiobook first, and then went back and actually read it. I thouroghly enjoyed each one. It is a great twist of fantasy/science fiction and a 80's pulp culture. I think anyone can truly enjoy this book, but if you grew up in the eighties, you will understand and enjoy the book that much more. One could argue that this book is just for people into gaming and pop culture, but it goes beyond that, it's a great piece of fiction, with characters I really enjoyed getting to know and was sad to part with at the end of the book. Thank you Ernest Cline for writing this book. This book made me laugh, and smile, and feel for the characters, which made for a great read. A movie about his book is supposed to be in the works, I look forward to a film adaption, but hope the essence of the book is not lost within it.

I was interested in this book from the beginning, but it took me a long time to get around to reading it. I wish I had purchased it the day it had come out, because by now, I could have reread it a few more times. Simply said, the book was fabulous. The idea that society could exist within a virtual reality game doesn't seem so outrageous the way Cline writes it. His reverence for the pop culture from the 1980s is charming and the inclusion of those references didn't seem gratuitous. They added to the storyline and gave the characters more depth. I couldn't help but be invested in the lives of Wade (or Parczival), H, Artemis, Shoto, or Dioto. I couldn't stop reading and wanted to find out what happened, but I was sad to see it end. I'm anxious to see if the movie, with Cline signed on as a screen writer, will do this book justice. I can't recommend this book enough.

Even though I grew up in the 70s, rather than the 80s, and was more heavily into RPGs than video games, I was blown away by this book--and a first novel at that!  It's not just a bunch of pop culture references and arcane gamer reminiscenses, Ready Player One is a well thought-out exercise in near-future scifi worldbuilding with relatable and sympathetic characters, thrilling twists and turns, well-organized, vicious, smart, and credible bad guys, humor, romance, trivia, and page-turning action.  Clearly one of the best books of the year, and one which will make an absolutley kick-ass movie.  I want all my friends (gamers, geeks, trivia mavens, and pop culture gurus, as well as mundanes) to know about this book now, not just because they will love it, but because I will be able to bask in the glory of having been the guy that told them about this incredible find.  Donald J. Bingle, top-ranked player of RPGA classic roleplaying game tournaments from 1985-2000 and author of Net Impact, Forced Conversion, and Writer on Demand: Tales of Gamers and Gaming.

This is the perfect book for anyone who enjoys science fiction or fantasy.  Ernest Cline does an amazing job of fusing together all aspects of scifi, fantasy, and the 1980s in this action-packed book.  Set in the future, this book follows the adventures of Wade Watts as he looks for an Easter Egg in the O.A.S.I.S.  The characters are well developed, and the plot is very interesting and compelling.  I have literally no complaints about this book, and I have recommended it to everyone I know who plays video games or loves science fiction. Anyone will enjoy this novel, but geeks especially will because they will understand and appreciate all the references. The book makes references about everything from Dungeons and Dragons to Doctor Who.

A fun nostalgic trip through my teen years, but all the pop culture references overwhelm the story. I would have enjoyed more time spent with the villain Sorrento, the Oasis, or the other gunters. I desperately wanted to learn more about the fall of society and the disconnect with the real word caused by Oasis addiction. The ending also left me a little disappointed. The impending doom never made me doubt the hero would be successful in his quest for the egg. Again, the story was fun and I was entertained the whole time, but it wasn't as deep as I had hoped. Now I'm stuck watching old Ultraman movies and digging up roms of old games to play on my smartphone.

I will be honest, I am not a big reader.  However, when I do read I like to read subjects that grab me don't let go until the end.  That is exactly what this book did.  It literally sucked me into the world of the future where OASIS is king and the only thing that matters is finding the 3 easter eggs buried by the games creator, as well as they the 3 gates they open.  This book is a joy to read from start to finish and as a former "hardcore" MMO player it really hit home.  It teaches a very valuable life lesson,  I wish others would follow.  This is a must read! And to the author, please write some more books like this one, fantastic work!

Picked it up. Couldn't put it down. While everyone has mentioned the exhaustive use of 80s references in their reviews, and the very elegant way that these are organic to the sorry, I'd like to focus on Cline's depiction of the future. While we've seen many different versions of dystopian futures, this one feels like its evolution is pulled directly from today's headlines. I loved his evocations of future housing, credit and social issues. Very modern and vivid and sadly too plausible. Wonderful book. Hope he has more stories from this world rattling around in his head. Great read, lots of fun and stays with you.

I enjoyed the suspense and humor enough to continue reading the book, which ought to say something. However, the plot is very weak, with countless episodes where the narrator seems in terrible danger, only to either 1) have an all-powerful outside character save him, or 2) use some sort of game/magic/scifi device to save himself. I'm not, nor ever have been a big gamer, and perhaps this is part of the reason I wasn't overly impressed. I won't give a rave review, nor will I crucify the novel, but I also won't read it again, and will probably forget it within minutes of starting my next book, whatever that may be.

If you are in your late 30s or 40s, you can't help but feel connected to Ready Player One.  Every bit of pop culture referenced in the book was a part of your youth.  Cline engages you on multiple levels.  The character or player development is a little disjointed, but the story is amazing.  I read the book in two sittings only because my eReader died midway through the book.  It was fascinating to see which movies, tv shows and games Cline included in the book.  It was almost as interesting to see what he omitted.  I can't wait to see what Ernest Cline does next.

I first found this book via an audiobook service. My husband and I both listened to it, and being children of the '80's, we both loved it. Then I decided my two sons would like it also because they're both "gamers", and they've both been exposed to our love of sci-fi and 80's culture. My 17 year old is currently reading it, and I'll pass it along to my 21 year old when he's finished with it. So far, my 17 year old loves the book also. If you know "gaming" lingo, like sci-fi, grew up in the 80's (or are really close to someone who did), this is the book for you!

To say I liked this book is an understatement.  Its cliché, but I could not put it down.  I don't normally write reviews, but this book definitely is an exception.  Cline really got you sucked in, almost each chapter was a cliff hanger.  It gets really geeky at some points, but stays approachable to any reader.  This is one of the best books I've read in a while.  As far as story goes, it's up there with "Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy".  Cline isn't quite as talented in his prose as Adams, but that fact doesn't hurt the characters or story in any way.

I normally avoid sci-fi like the plague but my new library mixes genres in the new release section so I picked this up and read the jacket. I was hooked before I even got started and haven't been that into a book for too long to remember. Excellent story and writing, although I skipped some more of the technical gamer stuff (last system I had was Super Nintendo ;)This has action, adventure, love, fantasy and futuristic aspects that are so believeable and realistic-it's made me want to try more sci-fi. Although I would bet they aren't all this good!!

This is another book I discovered from Cory Doctorow's recommendation, and it didn't disappoint. Being a child of the 80s, it was pretty hard to not get into the nostalgia of it all. You can read the synopsis, so I won't rehash it, but it's chock full of nerd culture references, action, internal strife, and especially someone to hate (sixers/IOI). Cline does a good job of involving the reader and making him really care about the problems his characters face, and actually consider if this is our future. I'll be looking for future books by Cline.

Calling all nerds: If you love movies, video games, and pop culture (especially from the '80s) you'll have a blast with Ready Player One. Cline tells a fast-paced story that's just as addictive as the virtual reality game at the center of his book. I couldn't put this one down, ravenously devouring it within just a few days. I needed to see how it would turn out, but didn't want it to end. Already thinking about re-reading it just so I can get lost in Cline's fascinating world all over again.

I'm not a big fan of 80s pop culture (though i did indeed grow up during those years), but I loved every page of Ready Player One. It's ridiculously clever, I constantly found myself nodding along with the descriptions of how the OASIS worked -- usually computer stuff in fiction is not very credible and seems there only to serve the plot. But I constantly found myself thinking "yes, that's exactly how that would work if such a thing existed." Just a fun, wonderful page turner.

I read a review of this book in Time magazine and could not wait to start. . .an adventure filled with cultural references to the '80s? Ready Player One didn't disappoint. It's an action filled page-turner that is clever, funny and nostalgic. Characters are a bit cartoonish and two-dimensional at times, but I didn't care; this is just solid fun from beginning to end, especially for those of us who grew up in that era. I read this book in three days; really an enjoyable read.

I loved this book:)  I couldn't stop reading it.  Sad to see it end, but a great journey.  It has been a long time since I felt so compelled to tell my friends about a book, to like it on Facebook, and write a glowing review on Amazon.  I was born in in 1971--so grew up pretty close to the timeline.  That being said--I think knowing the references only makes the book better, the story itself stands alone.  Only problem with finding a book like this so early in an author's career--nothing else to dive into after it is done.

Not a bad book, but it's been pretty severely over-hyped. Someone compared it to the experience of reading Snow Crash or Neuromancer for the first time and if that level of badassery is what you're expecting, you're in for an unforgivable disappointment. Without any especially interesting concepts to ponder you'll get through it pretty quickly and have a good time doing it, but the amount of frothing going on in the reviews above is a little weird. The book gave me a real sense of knowing exactly what was going to happen at every point - almost as if the author did a screen writing course, laid out all the structural points that make a successful hollywood movie, then wrote a book instead. Give it a go, but don't expect your mind to be blown or anything.

I actually listened to the audio version of this book, which is read by Wil Wheaton, but wanted to leave a review because I enjoyed this book so much.  I have suggested this book to most of my friends and plan to purchase a hard cover copy to read later.  I have even started looking into some of the 80s materials referenced in this book and find that I am enjoying most of it also.  My only complaint is that I really wish it wouldn't have ended because now I want to find more things like it.

I actually listened to the audiobook and begrudgingly followed through. The book is a complete pander fest for the "geek" crowd. Will Wheaton narrating exacerbate it over the edge. The excessive exposition though was what phoned it in for me. There's too much world building and backstory to trudge through. I really don't get the high praise and am pretty disappointed with it overall. I feel like "Ready Player One" is an excuse to talk about 80's videogames and movies.

I bought this book for me and a friend after listening to the audible version several times. One of my favorite books ever. Probably listened to it about 8 or so times in a year or so. Got one book for a friend and the other I took to a vintage video game convention and Ernest Cline signed my copy! Probably my favorite book and I'm 31 years old. Do yourself a favor and buy the book you won't regret it.

Never done a review before but this book needs to be known.  Best book I've read in a year.  I'm a 50 year old guy, not a video game person but this book was fascinating.  The twists and turns were outstanding but I was extremely disappointed that when I typed in Ernest Cline's name on Amazon there wasn't a bunch more written by this guy.  I'll be patient but hope the wait isn't too long...

If at any point in your life you enjoyed a book/movie/comic that even remotely resembled the scifi/fantasy/fiction genre; or if you have ever played a video game of any kind; or if you existed during or have any knowledge of pop-culture in the 80s you will love this book. Ernest Cline I tip my hat to you sir and I patiently await your next novel (but don't take too long please, my ADD geek brain can't handle it).

Loved this book. Listened to the audio version read by Wil Wheaton - he did an excellent rendition. I'm 63. You don't have to be cool and geeky to enjoy this science fiction/fantasy... if you engaged with early video games in the 70s and 80s, you'll find it nostalgic. One good thing about reading this as an oldster... I'll forget it quicker and get to listen to it again soon. 8^)

I haven't enjoyed a book like this in ages! I had just finished G.R.R. Martin's latest (my review?: golf calp) last evening and decided to start this book. I read it 'til the sun came up, took a short nap, and then finished it. The book is so riveting, so accessible, and so adventure-filled that I have a hard time imagining anyone with at least an ounce of geek in them not liking the hell out of it!

The big part of being a nerd is learning more than everyone else, memorizing your favorite movies, and levelling up higher than anyone else thought possible. This book celebrates that culture, and shows that it can be the even bigger nerd, with references and trivia I didn't know even existed. Share this with anyone you care about. It's what Halliday would have wanted.

Not normally my genre but I have to say I am glad I stumbled onto this book. I was on holiday at the four seasons in Sharm El Sheik and had 4 days relaxing by the sea on the beach...I couldn't put the book down. I finished it in three days. Just so fun and entertaining and the author is a fabulous writer; smart, creative and what an imagination. Bravo!

Amazing read. After the first few pages I was hooked and couldn't put it down. It uses a lot of 80's references but even though I was born in 1987 I was still able to understand the majority of them. Throughout the book I found myself getting goose bumps and excited as the story went along. Overall I would recommend this book to anyone who enjoys adventure novels, lived in the 80's, or any gamer.

I'm surprised there was no mention of Square Pegs (that I noticed), but this book brought back the flood of memories of having grown up in the 80's in a fast paced, action adventure that I couldn't put down. If you ever owned/played  an Apple ][, Atari, Colecovision, Intellivision or watched Star Trek, Firefly, Kikaida, Raiden, etc. this is a walk down memory lane wrapped in a apocalyptic future action-adventure story. I thoroughly enjoyed it!
This is an incredibly entertaining story, one that nerds and those who grew up in the 80s will especially enjoy. I'm sad the journey is over.
This is such a fantastic book. I wish it had a sequel. And they should totally make a movie out if it!

Anyone who grew up in the 1980s will enjoy this book.  Especially if you grew up in the 80s hanging out in arcades listening to the best decade of music ever.  Cline's knowledge of the 80s and how it mixes into the life of the protagonist is flawless.  It also serves as a reminder that no matter how comfortable we are in our current surroundings, sometimes you have to leave your comfort zone to do what is necessary.  Looking forward to his next novel!

I'm not going to lie, I had a hard time when this book devolved into pages of gushing about classic video games, music and movies.  Maybe I'm too old for this book (or maybe I'm too young?) but the nostalgia just didn't do it for me -- but when I pushed past that the book actually offered some decent reading.  A compelling narrative, with some strong characters and excellent twists.  On top of all that, a somewhat realistic depiction of hacking.  All in all, if you either loved the 80s or never experienced it, maybe the nostalgia will work for you, and make this book even better.

This book felt like a dumptruck full of winks to oldschool gamers, but the paper-thin storywas not too compelling, and the VR aspect was far too overstated for me to feel any true empathy for the protagonists.

A nostalgic geek romp through '80s Arcadia with a distinct YA feel. Fairly ironic in that anyone old enough to appreciate the nostalgia will be well beyond the age to appreciate the YA vibe of the book.  Nice enough if you discount the deus ex machina ad nauseum.

This is a great page-turner likely to appeal to fans of sci-fi with a soft spot for/fond memories of 80s pop culture! The book travels along at a good clip and once I started I ploughed through this in less than 24 hours - couldn't put it down. It's not a deep tome and there are no unexpected twists or turns, but it is a fantastic escapist read. Highly recommended!
Growing up in the 70's and 80's. I was the first person in my high school to code on an Atari 400. I could relate to everything in this book.This book played all the right notes
Although I know nothing about the 80s I still really enjoyed the book. Great concept. The ending is obvious, but the storyline is full of interesting twists.

Reading this book stirred so many memories from a simpler time in my life.  Every reference to classic computers, games or pop culture from the 80's made me smile.  Great story line as well.  This book will make a great movie.  Thanks to my son for recommending it for me.

This book captured everything a gamer born in the 80's would. Games as most individuals was also may escape from the "Real world". As every kid I was tasked with everything at an early age from eldest son, big brother and a pillar for my family. By immersing my self in games, I felt my soul being transported into a sword welding warrior, or a street fighter, even an Italian plumber that at times spit fire. So I thank Ernest Cline for making one of greatest fantasies come to life.
If you grew up in the 80s, you love video games, you like suspense novels, you have a penchant for obscure trivia or if you enjoy a great romance novel - this is the book for you.  ENJOY!

How did I miss this amazing book?  Just wonderful!  Completely wonderful!  If you have not read it, and you are into geeky things, then I highly suggest this book.  If you dont like it, you are stupid...

Great 80's nostalgia.  Kicked up a lot of memories with D&D; and spending Saturday afternoons in the arcade at the mall, where you would put your quarters on the rim of the machine to reserve your place in "line."  Ernie Cline is always an entertaining story teller and this one didn't disappoint.  There were some twists here and there but you never doubted the end would be rosy, and for me that detracted from the tension a little bit.  Overall a good read and looking forward to the next one.
I haven't been this engrossed by a book possibly ever.  I purchased it on a thursday morning and I finished it the following afternoon.  I couldn't put it down.
For all of those who grew up in the 80's this is a must read. Cline makes the reader nostalgic for a decade filled with video arcades, new wave music and feathered hair! Great book!

It has a unique storyline but was easy to follow. The characters are well drawn and you care about them. Really keeps your interest. Highly recommend, I am not a gamer but I throughly enjpyed reading this book.

At a certain point though, you'll become self aware that Cline is playing to this very connection and just when you start thinking "is this read turning into some sort of digital age circle jerk" Cline really starts to shine. Ready Player One by Ernest Cline is an immersive, coagulated soup of nostalgia and pop-culture reference that sticks in your pores, gets under your fingernails and dampens your hair. It's a tribute to a decade of excess and overload when everyman technology was on the cusp of finding real traction. These things are where the novel is boldly, reverentially, tediously exceptional. As a teenager in the 80's, I found great joy and remembrance in the mention of John Hughes' films, archaic (now) video games like Tempest and Defender and Space Invaders, and music from Rush and others, and the way that these elements were not only woven into the fabric of the story, but were critical to its progression. The dystopian future created in RPO is intriguing and insightful, if not exactly original, and the fact that it's biggest prize hinges on regressing by several decades is clearly where its strength lies. Wade is a nerd for the ages. His only real life is in his fake online persona residing in The Oasis, future's creative next step from World of Warcraft. The book revolves around Wade and his fellow gunters battling cyber villains in cyber space for a cyber prize that will translate to real money in the real world where neither he, nor his friends, spend any real time. It is here that the novel stumbles for me, and the reason I cannot give it highest marks. Cline's dialogue and passion are absolutely evident when he regales us with his expert knowledge of Pac-Man or obscure movie references, but these same traits are woefully unbalanced when he tries to generate the effect with action sequences and dialogue. A lot of the action happens off-line (no pun I swear) and is retold in a retrospective monologue by Wade. It works within the context of the story, but the residual taste leaves my bibliographic meter a little flat. The weakest part of the book is the direct interaction between characters. Often the exchanges are stunted and generate no real emotional connection to the reader. When I finished the book, I couldn't figure out if this was by design. I don't think it was, but if so, Cline is more brilliant that I gave him credit for. After all, in a world where people spend more time being cyber renditions of themselves, maybe direct exchanges between actual other humans would be clunky and unfulfilling. Ultimately, this book is salvaged and elevated by its exceptionally well-researched and communicated nostalgia. It was good enough to bring this well above the average.

To make things even better, the technology for the OASIS simulator is completely possible. In the world of gaming, anything is possible, and gaming technology is on its way to meeting up with the technology that was mentioned in the book. To be honest, the OASIS system might even make a gamer reader thing a bit about the Oculus Rift, which is an already existing virtual reality system. If you approach Ready Player One (RPO) with the right spirit, it's a fun read and a blast from the past -- especially if you're old enough to remember plunking quarters in games like Asteroids, Galaga and Dig Dug at your local arcade. The book has several things going for it -- first and foremost, a unique and engaging spin on the threadworn dystopia genre. If nothing else, Cline is a genius for combining his love for eighties arcade and geek/pop culture with yet another post-apocalyptic tale. On top of that, he knows how to tell a story -- the pacing moves quickly, and I stayed up late several nights to read "just one more chapter". And I'll admit it -- I enjoyed all the references to the eighties -- Zork, Rush, Family Ties, and the Atari 2600, among many, many others. Cline not only loves that decade, but his knowledge of arcade and pop culture from that time (I almost said "era"!) is deep and wide. The book is a trivia-lovers' dream-come-true: arcane tidbits are sprinkled throughout the story. However: like another reviewer, I'm a bit surprised at all the five-star reviews. While fun, there are definite shortcomings. As many others have pointed out, there's a lot of explaining in the story -- telling, rather than showing, in other words. Once or twice, I wouldn't mind, but it happens a LOT. My other major complaint is with the characters, who unfortunately fall into the most predictable stereotypes. So it's a mixed bag. But it's a FUN mixed bag, and I definitely recommend it to anyone who has even a passing interest in a fresh take on the dystopia genre.

I'll make this quick. Read it in 24 hours and have re-read it since. If you grew up with an Atari, went to arcades, played D&D;, watch campy 80's flicks or own a Rush box set, read this book, it is for you.

Great Sci-Fi read. Reminiscent or Ender's Game and a few dystopia books I read in my younger days. Lot's of 80's and modern cultural references really pulls together the Ready Player One world with ours.

Ready Player One is by far one of my favorite books of all times. I was a kid in the 80's - raised on Super Mario Bros, The Legend of Zelda, Back to the Future and the Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles. I found Ready Player One after hearing that Wil Wheaton had voiced the audio book, and while I wasn't sure about the book itself, I downloaded a copy from Audible thinking it would be entertaining to listen to Wheaton's narration while sitting at my desk at work. Needless to say, I was wonderfully surprised by this novel... the characters were well built, the story engrossing, and the 80's pop culture references gave me flash backs to my childhood as well as a few new movies to add to my Netflix queue. Wheaton's voice was expressive, changing with each character, portraying surprise, anger, sadness... whichever the story called for... making the "movie" in my head that much more realistic. I found it nearly impossible to tear myself away, listening not just at the office, but also in the car on my ride home and even when I could sneak in some free time in the evenings. I didn't notice any long, drawn out, unnecessary explanations, the writer hooked me right away and the pace never slowed until the final sentence was delivered. I will be keeping an eye on this author for certain, hoping for a sequel or an entirely new story. Until then, here's hoping someone picks up the movie rights soon!

Loading....screech, screech. If that is familiar, you will enjoy RP1. Geek out in the virtual world of Oasis and join the hunt for the hidden 'Easter egg' in this game. James Halliday, the fabulously wealthy creator of Oasis dies, leaving his fortune to the first gamer who can find the 3 keys to open the hidden gates and win his game. Everybody uses Oasis to escape from reality and live out a better life online. Wade Watts, a.k.a. Parzival, an orphaned teenager living in poverty, becomes one of the 'Gunters' (egg hunters) and is the first person to find the first key. This book is very Anglo-American and is a clever fusion of the 80s with the future Earth, a planet ruined by our depletion of its assets and in permanent recession. If you liked the films Surrogates and Total Recall, then you should enjoy this, particularly if you are into arcade games and on-line gaming, or used to be. It is also a great book for teenagers because they can all identify with the futuristic concepts in the book unless they have been living off-planet. Virtual School, anyone? Clearly well-researched and written fluently. I have no doubt that the author is an anorak of the highest calibre and his web site is funny. Why haven't I been offered a lift in an Ectomobile? Watch out for the film - the rights have been bought by Warner Bros. (I received this book free from the UK Vine program).
I originally borrowed this book from a friend who recommended that I read it.  I took it on vacation with me and couldn't put it down.  Fantastic read, I loved it so much I purchased my own copy.
I wasn't a kid during the 1980s, I wasn't a video game fan, but I really enjoyed this book. New and retro at the same time. Entertaining, good characters, full-blown virtual world. Total fun.

This is an intelligent, funny first novel by Ernest Cline. I would call it a mashup of different styles. On the one side it is scfi, with a deep romantic streak, but also it is adventure mixed with suspense. The star is Wade Watts, a young overweight kid who lives for spending time in the "oasis", a gaming universe, that for the inhabitants of the book  is preferable to so-called real life in 2044. in this gaming universe people can be whatever they want.  Wade is known as parzival a super powered alter ego who is everything Wade is not. This story also has a romance, Wade loves a girl called Artemis, a fellow gamer and competitor who is on a quest along with Wade to save the oasis from the evil "sixers" a corporation, that seeks to dominate the "oasis" and make it a pay as you play system. This is the chief antagonist to Wade. He and his fellow competitors, called hunters, wreak havoc over this universe fighting the sixerrs at every turn. The novel has just enough suspense, mixed with heart to be a real page-turner. I loved the 80s feel to the whole book. If you grew up during this time, you will remember many of the references and laugh. I glossed over much of the plot, because many of fellow reviewers have talked about it. I do recommend this novel, and I think you will have a good time.
If you are over 40 and lived through the 80's playing video games, then this book is for you. So many references to games, movies, and the staggering amount of time you wasted as a kid.

Ready Player One is a brilliant/entertaining/thrilling love letter to the 80's -- a decade jam-packed with game-changing TV shows, movies, and video games. Author Ernest Cline (he wrote the film Fanboys) covers it all in his 370-page quest novel that's been dubbed The Matrix meets Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory. That's a pretty astute comp, but there's also so much more going on in this book. From the get-go, you'll be drawn in by an A+ prologue that sets up the brilliant conceit of the story and ends with a revelation by the first-person narrator that will cause you to smile and start turning the pages. And be prepared to turn the pages at a rapid rate. I could not put the book down and essentially read it in three sittings -- the third being a "are-you-kidding-me-this-book-is-sofa-king-good" marathon to the end. If you are of the generation that grew up in the 80's, be prepared to relive your youth -- everything from Dungeon & Dragons to Atari to Pac Man to John Hughes films to Star Wars to War Games to Duran Duran to Rush. It's all in there. And it's utilized and referenced in such a brilliant way. I am obviously avoiding telling you much about the premise, because I do not want to ruin any of the fun of discovering it all for yourself. Trust me, it's a fun ride. Now get on it.
This is now one of my all-time favorite books. If you're a pop culture geek and/or a child of the 80s, this will speak to you like few other things will. I can't recommend this enough.

My score would verge on a 4 or 4.5 if I hadn't loved the story itself as much as I did. The build-up and dissipation of suspense, along with the (virtual) world-building, were excellent. The countless 80's references got old and played out, but I still enjoyed many of them. He didn't just make 80's references; he went back to the 60's and 70's and forward to recent years with his mention of video game consoles, authors, and TV series. But every reference made an abrupt halt after the XBOX. I couldn't help but wonder why the author didn't put forth the effort to invent the future of pop-culture, since it was such an integral part of the storytelling - it was as though nobody had released a new movie, video game, or book since 2010, even though the story takes place in the 2040's. That was a huge oversight that detracted from the immersive nature of the story. He does do quite a bit of explaining (ie., telling), but a lot of it was interesting, so I didn't mind. Starting every other sentence with "Then" during the action-oriented sequences had the same effect that using "Suddenly" or "All of a sudden" does - it was distracting. Finally, and unrelated to the writing itself, Wil Wheaton did a great job with the narration in the audiobook version.
because there are several lengthy reviews prior to mine, saying (in essence) the same thing I want to: If you've ever in your life played Dungeons & Dragons, do not miss this book!
It had me enamored from start to finish. I couldn't put it down. Everyone would enjoy this book, but it is especially interesting for people like myself that grew up in the 1980s.
If you grew up in the 80's playing video games and watching a lot of TV and movies, then this book is for you! I breezed through it in a few hours and was engrossed every second!

What a wonderful story, it would have been easy for the author to craft this story as a dystopian struggle, but there are for more to it. I was oddly reminded of Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory as the characters travel through a myriad of world in search of a rewards offered by an eccentric multibillionaire. They progress through the hero's journey and change, suddenly the main character is dealing with all the normal issues of being a teenager while he is in a virtual world...one that he is more comfortable in then the real world. The homages to the early era of video games and 80's culture are epic in scope and you will find yourself bursting out laughing more times than you can count. The story of Wade aka Parzival as he embarks on an epic quest that the entire world has been trying to solve for years is a joy to read, the challenges are deadly and confront him in the virtual world and real world. Perhaps the greatest part of the novel comes at the climax where he meets the avatar of the games creator who shares some hard won knowledge with Wade that can be applied to the reader as well. If you enjoy novels with a fast paced plot, wonderful characters (both heroic and nefarious), and satisfying endings then this is the novel for you!
I was in my 20's during the 80s and loved the pop culture and video game references...but the story is so good and the action so exciting that I think it would appeal to anyone.
This book is tailor-made for anyone and everyone who grew up watching movies, playing video games or listening to music in the 80's or 90's. I look forward to reading it again!

I think this is one of the rare instances in which the movie, if it ever comes to fruition, will be substantially better than the book.  The cardinal sin that Cline commits is having all of the nostalgia and agonizingly long explanations of 80s stuff get in the way of the plot.  The plot is great galloping fun.  The writing style is a big gallumphing bore. It is Overly-repetitive, full of cliche as much as it is full of the 80s referential stuff. The other sour point for me, was that for a piece of work with a decidedly athiest  bent, there were quite a few instances of deus ex machina. I wonder if Wade learned that in his latin class?  I don't mean this review to be all negative, there were points when i was genuinely excited, the final battle being one that comes to mind.  But there were more parts/elements that I found somewhat troublesome. The treatment of the Japanese characters, and Wade's initial showdown with Sorrento and its aftermath.  At any rate, if a person is into dan brown or tom clancy type books, this will likely satisfy in terms of written quality, but a person will get the most enjoyment out of it if they have a deep connection to late 70s and 80s nerd culture AND don't need a book to be particularly well written.
Real easy and enjoyable read, but this book is kind of derivative. If you've read Snow crash you'll understand what I mean. Again not bad just not mind blowing or ambitious.
One of the geekiest, most enjoyable books I've read this year.  If you grew up dorking out in the 80's or 90's, read this book.  The allusions and call backs are fantastic.

Wow. This was great. I am a child of the 80's, and this book made me think... maybe that's not so uncool. This book is heavy on the geek culture, but though I was an outsider amongst nerds (a computerless dweeb who was jealous of the gangs of Dungeons and Dragoners and their Friday meetings) I still got into it. Just when the nostalgia was starting to wane, HE DROPPED MAXX HEADROOM IN THERE! Lots of action and adventure - this thing had me riding all the way through it. The only thing that keeps me from giving it 5 stars is the most common complain in sci fi. Civilization is falling apart, no one can get a job, but everybody has a computer and is online all the time in this uber reality. It still takes credits (money) to go places and have "things" when you are in the OASIS, but yet part of society's problem is that everyone is spazzed outline all the time. There's a power crisis, but again, everyone's online using these super powerful computers and there's tons of solor power in use. I gave the story a pass, though, as those things sort of faded into the bakground. A really fun ride. And a trip through memory lane for a child of the 80's. OH - and this must be a movie. This would be an INCREDIBLE movie!!

A great audio book for any 1980's video game nerd. I put the first CD in and I was hooked in minutes. It took me 3 or 4 days to listen to the entire book. Every time that I had to stop and you know eat and sleep all I could think about was when I would get to listen to it some more. I am seriously considering listening to the entire book all over again it was great. The book is about a very poor boy who spends a lot of his time in the virtual word called "The Oasis". It is a virtual realty that the entire planet logs into for multiple hours a day. They put on boots, gloves, body suits and wear visors that allow them to feel like they are in this fantasy world. Well soon into the book one of the creators of the world dies and leaves his fortune up to the first person to solve these riddles and find the hidden "Easter eggs" in the virtual world. A lot of the book is about 1980's video games, tv, and trivia. The main character has to fight against other players and corporations all trying to win the fortune (several billions of dollars). Its a great suspense that will have you on the edge of your seat. I highly recommend this to all my fellow 80's and 90's video game geeks.
if you grew up loving video games and everything 80's your going to love this book! I sent my copy to a friend and i'm buying another copy as a gift for another friend.

I really wanted to love this novel. I grew up in the late 80's and have some nostalgia about things, even though I wasn't old enough to really play video games until the early nineties. I loves some of the references to things I remembered such as the Intellivision system and movies and music, but about half-way into the novel I started to feel like all the references were really taking away from the story. I got impatient with the book, I wanted to know what happened to the protagonist, not a bunch of facts the 80's. The novel is set in the future in Ohio, in a semi-post-apocalyptic world and nothing really new or interesting jumped out at me. The detailed explanations about how MMORPGS worked (currently) was unnecessary, anyone who made it to that point in the book is probably familiar enough with it. I understand he was trying to include a broad audience though, so maybe some explanation is required, but it certainly left fewer things up to the imagination. So far the book has felt like an MTV pop-up video from the 80's, all the quirky facts are taking away from what the book is trying to convey and even the main story line is a bit transparent and lacking in substance.

This is my new favorite book. It is not prose, but it is so well written that the writing style itself is unnoticeable, you just get enveloped in the story. I have not had this much fun reading a book since I discovered Tolkien in Junior High School (OK, 30 years ago, haha!). This book is just FUN to read, but I grew up in the 80's and every single page in here is full of SO many references that reminded me of my childhood. I grew up near an arcade, played tabletop games, read sci-fi and fantasy books, and watched all those wonderfully cheesy 80s Jim Henson movies. This book will really resonate with fellow geeks who enjoyed D&D;/AD&D;, arcade games, Colossal Cave Adventure, Pac Man, and even Kaiju movies! All the things that make me weird are celebrated in this book. This author must be my doppelganger. :D Highly recommended for anyone who enjoys sci-fi (the actual plot/action/characters are well developed also - this book is well-rounded in so many ways). In a freaky way, I can see our society quickly going in the technologically dystopian fantasy setting of this novel. I have purchased this on Kindle AND paper copy. Kudos to Ernest Cline for such an engaging story.

Very few books can immerse me as much as this book did. A touch of Ender's Game, a dab of Tron (80s original and Legacy), and top it off with all of nerddom nostalgia from the 80s. This book will without a doubt bring adults who grew up in the 80s back to the time of their childhood. Just as if they were there with Marty McFly in the DeLorean zipping through time. Though I wasn't very familiar with some of the nerd lore throughout the book, I would stop and look up what I was reading just to get a better backdrop of what I wanted the setting of the book to be. The pace of the book is so well planned out and some of the things the characters say are just downright hilarious! Every page just leads to the next and you feel a flow which is paramount for any kind of book. I feel that this book stands out among most in that it's an idea that triggers the imagination and gets us to go deeper into our own sci-fi worlds. It extracts concept art and all kinds of interesting things to mold them into a story that we feel would best resemble the story we're reading. I highly recommend this book to anyone who's looking for imagination, creativity, and just a great time reading.
I downloaded this book on a friend's recommendation and read the book in a week. Best fiction book I have read in a year! After the first chapter you will be hooked!

I purchased this book for myself, a hard-core science fiction fan who felt she was out of reading options and so had to resort to a video game book set in the near future.  I never liked Tron in the 80's and anything that reminds me of Tron now is immediately off the list.  I was a little afraid this would be a Tron - but I needn't have worried.  I haven't enjoyed a book this much since The Hunger Games.  Very easy to read, fast paced, yet thoughtful narrative really develops our protagonist.  I do wish authors would nix the environmental BS in the near future dystopia - it's funny, with all the really dating name brand stuff (which I normally HATE in anything science fiction, but which totally works here) the environmental thing will be what really dates this book in the future.  So, like I said - I bought this book for myself but now have it on my video-game obsessed 9th grade teen's reading list for our homeschool year.  This story might be what seals the deal with him as far as the whole reading vs. gaming war goes.  A+++ 5 stars totally fun and interesting book.  Well worth the outrageous publisher Kindle price, if you're worried about that.

I cannot even begin to explain how epic this book is.  It combines everything that is awesome about the eighties, being a video gamer, comic book collector, music and movie buff all into one awesome novel.  When reading this book I felt like I was logged into World of Warcraft, while reading my first comic book, watching Blade Runner, listening to a hair band while eating a bowl of Mr. T cereal.  I felt transported back to my childhood and into the story.  I am a avid reader and have not been so engrossed in a book like this in a long time.  It wasn't just the nostalgia; it was the world inside of a world inside of a game written to perfection.  If you enjoy 80's pop culture or video games or role playing or anything epic dork, stop reading my review and go buy this book.  I just finished the book on my tablet 2 minutes ago and immediately logged in to write this review, and to buy the Hardcover version.  I am usually content with just a digital read, but this book deserves its due place on my shelf.  My respect to you Mr. Ernest Cline for the amazing job you did on this book.  I am now a fan for life.
An enormously entertaining read, especially for those who lived through the 80s.  And an essential reference for those who want to re-live the 80's as well!

This is such an amazing book! I don't read a lot of futuristic stuff, but this is by far the best I have ever read. Characters come to life and you fall in love with every single one of them. Cline is such a talented writer and I wish this book would be popular and famous, because it rightfully deserves so. It can be read by all age groups, 11 to infinity, this book is appealing. The only reason I think eleven is a good starting age is because it does have cursing. There are no sex scenes though. Anyways, I think the plot line was out of this world. There are so many twists and turns. And when I say twist and turns, I mean crap your pants holy mother of god that is so good twist and turns. I'm never this enthusiastic about books of this genre, but it blew me away how much I didn't want to stop reading it. There are funny parts, sad parts, and full of action parts, as there are no boring moments. It is a really easy read, except a few confusing words sometimes. This book will only take a day to read for good readers, having 372 pages in it. There should be a Ready Player Two. I highly recommend it.

This was a very enjoyable read. It had a dystopian future with a likable protagonist who was intelligent, funny and fully in command of his abilities. I liked the premise of the book...the solving of a complicated game by a brilliant billionaire who grew up in the 1980s and stocked his game with tons of pop references. I am and was not a computer game geek so I missed some of the references but did remember many of the movie ones, which was fun to encounter in a book. While the writing of the book flowed and kept me reading as there were constant twists and turns that held your interest as well as the cool descriptions of the inside of computer game adventures, some of these descriptions went on slightly too long. I wanted more interaction with human characters rather than straight computer step by steps, which, I have to admire Cline for, were easy to understand even for a non-computer person. When I got human interaction, and there was some including an adolescent love story, that too was enjoyable. I'll certainly be on the look-out for Cline's next book. Job well done.
I loved the story premise and the multitude of 80's references.  The characters were quite well drawn and likeable.  No big surprises but fun to read.
Enjoyed this book immensely.  Blew through it in less than a week.  Great book for fans of pop culture and video games.  You will not be disappointed.

While this novel seems to struggle with ambivalence between memoir and traditional narration, the magic and excitement stem from the author's solid grasp of contemporary and classic video game technology as well as 1980s pop culture. The high points of the novel rely on readers' own knowledge of and experience with the video games, music, and movies mentioned throughout the story: the more familiar the content, the more intimately relatable the characters and events are. The low points of the novel are few but significant. There is a certain part of the story in which a lack of narrative development could leave readers disoriented and therefore disappointed, especially since a slight revision on the author's part could have substantially increased the suspense for that section of the novel; and major social and economic draws are left unexplored - rich mines of character growth and multidimensional storytelling left untapped. Overall, however, reading this novel should be a good, fun experience for gamers and those seeking nostalgic thrills.

My son was required to read this book prior to entering his freshman year at a state university, and parents were highly encouraged to read it, too. I was expecting to be bored to tears reading some sort of milk toast sort of sci fi novel, but was immediately caught up in the first few pages with the characters and premise of the search for the futuristic "golden ticket". The characters show great depth of emotion, moral challenges and evolution along the way. An added plus for grown ups: Having grown up (survived?) in the 70s and 80s - what fun it was to come across references page after page to some of my favorite movies, music and trivia along the way - it was the ultimate "easter eggs for grown ups" (if you read the book, you'll understand that reference). "Ready Player One" is a fast and easy read that spans the often difficult generation gap from ages 18 to 48 flawlessly. My son loved it too and we had some great conversations about it while we both read it - when was the last time THAT happened?

I am a 72-year old female who has never played a video game in my life, but this is one of the best books I have ever read.  The plot is so original and the action so intense that it is impossible to put down.  Probably the best part of the book is the nostalgia for the 1980's pop culture it invokes.  Anybody alive during that time who is of a certain age will be entertained by the constant references to movies, books, TV, video games (early editions) and popular music.  There is a nod to early games (Dungeons and Dragons), before video games.  The virtual world is as real as the "real" world in this book.  I found myself unable to sleep because I could not put the book down.  To make it worse, I was reading on a Kindle, so I could not skip ahead and cheat to find out what happens.  It is like a wild roller coaster ride.  I highly recommend this book to anyone who qualifies as a geek of any variety (it also makes constant references to Star Trek and Star Wars).  If you like Sci Fi, you will like this book.

I thoroughly enjoyed this book! It was full of nostalgia and excitement and a great ride. I loved listening to Parzival talk about trivia because I know most of what he was referring to since I too, am an 80's geek. I played all the games he refers to and watched all the movies he talked about. I also loved the concept of having worlds like the LoTR world and the Star Wars and Star Trek world. So cool! It felt in some ways like going back in time to my teen years and who doesn't love that? I also loved the potential love interest that develops and the twists at the end. I will say I'd HATE to live in Wade's world because it was such a depressing place and the corporation that them reminds me a lot of some of the companies (and our government) out there today. Not sure I'm looking froward to the movie though as it seems like they're going to have to sacrifice much to pull it off since there were literally hundreds of worlds mentioned and just getting the rights to some of them would make the budget skyrocket.

I dont think I've ever been quite so immersed in Geek Culture as I was while reading Ready Player One by Ernest Cline, and I loved every minute of it. This is an intelligent, fun take on the scavenger hunt, scifi adventure story genre. As someone who was also a teenager in the 1980's I loved that the clues for the hunt were all related to 80's pop culture. Made me so nostalgic for Duran Duran, Billy Idol, Family Ties et al. The online world OASIS at the center of the story is so immersive and pervasive that almost the entire world is conducting the majority of their lives online and checking out of the real world to do so. To many, the lives lived in the world of OASIS are more real and fulfilling than any thing they could achieve anywhere else, and the edges between on line and reality is very much blurred.The author doesn't shy away from this inevitable if unintended consequence of OASIS and provides a subtle cautionary tale weaved through the narrative.  An over all great reading experience.

Just finished this great book, cheated thou and used the audio version read by William "Wil" Wheaton who is best known for Star Trek: The Next Generation, or his recent parts on The Big Bang Theory. Not only was the book great, but I was amazed by the job Wheaton did reading it. If you like fantasy, science fiction, computer, online gaming and loved the eighties, this book could be the one for you. I grew up in the 70-80's and my first computer was a Texas Intruments TI 94/A with a tape drive, we're talking before Commodore 64.  This was 1981 hardware;  Memory: 16 Kb-48Kb RAM, 26Kb ROM. You would spend money on a code book, five days typing, and two more days debugging to get a cheap version of Donkey Kong. I am a mid 40s computer nerd who back in the day could roll many if not most Atari games, including Pacman which always took me 1 hour 43 minutes to roll.  The language and discription in the book took me back, way back to a time before internet and Amazon. Two thumbs up, way up!
Wonderful, rollicking adventure pitting gritty, gutsy geeks against the soulless corporate machine - a brilliant book worthy of your time!

This is my favourite book of all time. This book is everything I want in a book, all my geeky fantasies in one piece of work. I picked this book up at the book store near where i study and began reading it on the train home, I was so engrossed in the book I actually missed my stop. I ended up finishing the book in 3 sitting, the last of those sessions ended at 5 am in the morning. when you read this book it sucks you in. As you probably know the books main appeal is that it has tons of 80's pop culture references, from movies, TV, anime, music, games and even the fashion. I myself was born in the 90's but have always had a soft sport for 80's Si-Fi and video games. The only thing I'm going to complain about is that my favourite movie of all time wasn't even mentioned once ;( and that's Aliens 1986, apart from that every other geeky thing I could think of got a mention (even Buckaroo Banzai). So buy this book now before the movie comes out and get your geek on.

Ernest Cline's story of a massive online world is reminiscent of such ideas as Tron, where there is an entire world in the circuits. He provides a great storyline with funny and nostalgic references from the beginnings of video games and geeks. However, the story can lack substance at some parts, where it becomes hard to imagine the things being described and at times the writing is just a bit amateur. However, imagining the things being described could be hard due to the fact that most of the things are from the pure imagination of Cline. The book also felt like it was on the verge of being more young adult. I found myself imagining it as a kids movie, and then I would read the occasional bad word and rememeber that it was written for adults. Overall, the book is a wonderful ride for any geek or pop culture fanatic of the early geek days. The writing style can get amateur at times, but the overall epicness and fun of the story will keep you going to the end.

For anyone that loves a really fast paced read, Ready Player One is one of those unique sci-fi/fantasy novels that was very easy to get into from page one.  It is fast paced and you will be hard pressed to put it down.  The main characters of Parzival, Aech, & Arte3mis are well thought out and you can easily find yourself identifying with some of their feelings of excitement, anxiety, and even aloneness as they make their way through the layers of the game to reach the ultimate prize.  The experience in the Oasis is fast paced and brilliantly executed with all the attention to such detail where I felt myself knowing many of the 1980 references and felt immersed in the oasis itself!  I also loved the presence that IOI created where you had once again good versus evil and the race it created in the Oasis. It is easy to fall under the spell of this writer and I have recently heard that Spielberg is interested in directing this book as a movie! I can't wait!!

A great read, especially for fans of video/computer games. The writing style is excellent and offers many references to video games (past and present) as well as to the sci-fi world more generally. Ready Player One is a page-turner, offering just enough questions and hints along the way to keep the reader constantly wondering what will happen next and what new secrets this world has in store. The writing paints a picture of a world that might-be, if we were to focus in on our virtual personas and live in that "plugged in" world. The reader can't help but root for the main character, while wondering about the intricacies of the life he is leading and the relationships that he has developed. This book can also lead a person to question where society is going with technology, which can strike philosophical musings underneath the fun reading of exciting characters in the virtual world. I highly recommend this book; I couldn't put it down!
This book is an amazing tribute to the emergence of video gaming. I couldn't put it down. More later, I've got a game to go play...
A thrilling, addictive read, even for someone unfamiliar with many of the books '80s references.  Psyched for the film adaptation!
it was a fun book but definitely not great. it read like a selfindulgent fanfiction of the 80's. it'll make a great movie someday
Absolutely loved this book.  If you are a fan of the 80's, video games, MMORPG's, and geek culture, you will love this book too!

w-o-w this book, it made me laugh so hard in so many areas. I couldn't put it down for too long I needed to know what was going to happen next. I didn't know what to expect going into this book, but with in the first chapter I was in love with it. Every moment I read this book I fell more and more in love with wade, and the other characters. I love the relationship between Wade and Aech, it remind me so much of my husband and his best friend. I couldn't help but laugh at some of the stuff they would say. If you love video games and dystopian books (I personally don't even like dystopian books) I highly recommend you read this. While some areas of the book could have been better, I still loved the story and how easy it was to fall into this world of OASIS I want to live in this world, and it has made its way to number one of my favorite books this year. I cried at the end because I didn't want it to be over yet.
I ddn't want this book to ever end.I would love to see a sequel. It was pretty long but I would keep reading if there was more.

This is a fun and very easy read for those who like 1980's video games and pop culture. It's not deep and wasn't meant to be. This is a roller coaster ride through 80's nostalgia in the form of a video game in book form. Ready Player One is a world where everyone is plugged into the video game OASIS. When the creater of OASIS dies he leaves his massive fortune to whomever can solve and win his last game within the virtual game. This pits our hero Parzival and his friends against an evil corporation to see who will complete the quest first. Along the way there are many 1980's references dropped. Some work well within the story and some are just thrown out because that's what this book is about: a love of 1980's video game a pop trivia. Ready Player One is entertaining enough but not a "year's 10 best" book for me. I recommend this to old-school video game fanatics first and 80's pop culture lover's second.

Having seen this book pop up several times on blogs and other places I read about tech, I thought I'd finally give it a try. As a teenager in the 80s, it almost feels written for me, even though it feels more like a young adult novel. It's a real page-turner, and has an interesting premise. If there's one criticism I have of the book, it's that the author gets a little too into the details as he describes everything about what it's like to exist in the dystopian future of the novel + the virtual world of the Oasis. I was impressed that the author had thought through all of the details, but I don't think I needed all the exposition of those details, even though they were described fairly economically. The characters were moderately developed, and I read it quickly, but it was long enough that I felt like I got to enjoy it. I'll definitely be back for Ernest Cline's next book. In fact, already pre-ordered.

I bought this book solely on the hype created by its reviews... money well spent.  I am a product of the eighties so the story-line and associated subject matter couldn't have been more apropos - but "Ready Player One" exceeded my expectations.  I actually smiled and had to put the book the book down for a moment when Cline referenced the film "Better Off Dead" - not by using the title of the movie - but rather by mentioning an obscure Howard Jones' song that plays in the background of one of the most famous scenes from the movie - "like to get to know you well" indeed.  I felt like I was part of the game as I realized what he was writing about and could hear the song in my head and see the scene in my mind.  I immediately put the soundtrack to the film on in the background for the rest of my reading of the novel.  Well done Mr. Cline.  Thank you for a terrific piece of writing.  Keep up the good work.

Let me start off by saying this is a pretty realistic view from a 17 year old boy.  It can be crude and it can be a bit one sided.  Like a adolescent.  That being said, I grew up in the 80’s every reference it points to I know.  This book in a nutshell it a cross between The Matrix (my favorite movie) and every Scifi and Fantasy movie I have ever seen.  The main Character is looking for an Easter Egg in the game to earn complete power over the Oasis and receiving $200 Billion.  He must have a working knowledge of everything 80’s.  Great Great book.  I wish some of the crude language and situations were not in the book because it takes away from the beauty of the book.  100 would make the book perfect.  I think I would give it a 95%  but still well into the 5 star range.  I don’t want to give too much about the book but if you love Video games, and virtual reality, and 80’s you will LOVE this book.

I met a man while at thee hospital, and as he lay in his bed before his post-op physical therapy he sat in his bed and read this book: "Ready Player One". Being one who literally judges all the books I read by the cover (both the outside artwork and the inside description), I asked him about the novel. He shared with me the a general summary and his love of his ability to relate to the book, because he grew up in the time. As I read this book on my own later, I couldn't help but think constantly of how I wished I knew more about 80's pop culture. The thing about Ernest Cline's novel though is that...it doesn't matter. ANY gamer can find himself of herself able to totally relate to the characters because, they are gamers as well. I think that is something that transcends the generation difference, and even if it doesn't Cline provides a nice description of a lot of the references. A very nice book.

This is one of those books I just happened to stumble upon in the Amazon top sci-fi list and picked up because the summary seemed interesting...but holy **** I had no idea how incredibly epic this book would actually be!  From start to finish I couldn't put it down, i mean this book has everything I could ever dream of wanting all in one package.  Its got 80's pop culture from VR gaming, 8-bit gaming, 80's classic rock, 80's sci-fi film to anime, romance, and even the BTTF Delorean!  This book def has a permanent spot on my top ten of all time.  As a software engineer and have always been a computer geek and Cline just hit all the right spots from start to finish and even made me tear up at times with the endless references to 80's pop culture as well as classic themes in computer science and gaming.  Get this book now and start studying the Almanac...before the Sixers get their hands it...

I bought this book for my 14 year-old son who was getting into 80's stuff over a year ago and loves computers.  Out of books and bored, I decided to take a peek and fell in love with it.  As a 35 year-old Star Wars loving girl geek, I found myself enjoying what I thought would be a kids book.  Yes there are many 80's reference and there are some long expos that frankly I actually liked, but then I'm nerdy like that, however this book is not for everyone.  I read the one star reviews and realized that the people who wrote them, lost sight of the fun and magic we all lost when we grew up.  I also loved that the Ernest Cline is from Austin as I am just down the road and hope to go to a signing soon.  If you love Star Wars, had a Apple 2, played Dungeons and Dragons, love John Hughes movies and know who Buckaroo Banzai is, then get this book as I know you will love too!  Geek it Up Mr. Cline!

This was a fun ride through a virtual world imbued with 1980s pop culture references to video games, movies, music and books. I am by far not a gamer but was somehow intrigued by the premise of this book that took us into the heart of a contest played out through a series of video and movie games in a completely on-line world. I am glad I finally gave in and read it. I enjoyed spending time in the OASIS world and getting to know the characters. While there are some aspects of Cline's world that I question (one would think Wikipedia, the fist bump and other current cultural phenomena would have been replaced by other things by 2045), in the end I enjoyed discovering this virtual world and slipping into the mindset of a gamer for bit.
