I also enjoyed the bits of veiled social commentary embedded here and there on the environment and escapism. Overall an interesting and enjoyable read.
Ernest takes the reader on an amazing journey through the future while incorporating 80's pop culture. This is a must read!

I am not an avid reader at all...most of my books are biogrophies or non-fiction...books about The Brady Bunch, Gilligans Island, Little Rascals...and bookss about the top grossing fils of all time...all pop-culture stuff.  I heard about this book, and my wife, who reads all the time, told me to give it a try.  And I am glad I did.  I couldnt put this down.  Took me about a week to finish, and I could have finished in one night if I didnt have to go to work...the story was great, suspensful, funny, heartwarming.  The pop culture references were hysterical, even if I didnt get ALL of them.  I was a child of the 70's and 80's so I really enjoyed the homage to some of my favorite things.  It really played up my alley.  If your not into reading, but love pop culture stuff, this book would be perfect for you.  Now if I can oly get some recomendations for other books similar...!!!

I do not claim to be an all knowing geek of  80's pop culture but I am a boomer and do remember some games and movies from that era. This book was so much fun to read because it brings old memories of those days literally back to life. For example the author mentions the music from RUSH. I love their music always have and their new album Clockwork Angels is awesome much like their older stuff. He also talks about old video games like GALAGA. I used to play that game lots of fun. The author is a very visual writer. For example he writes about how Wade (parzival) steals IOI secure data while literally sleeping in a little shelf and working in his little cubicle as an indentured servant to find a way to deactivate a shield  so that the gunters can enter Anoraks Castle to enter the third gate. The book seems so real I don't see how a good movie could not come out of this.

*best Comic Book Guy voice* Best... Book... Ever!  From the first pop culture reference, I was hooked... RPGs, anime, video games, love, loss, surprises, the 80s, the future, lots of badies, and one hell of an adventure! I had never even heard of Ernest Cline before I chanced across this book (although, I subsequently learned he penned the movie Fan Boys) and decided to take a chance on something that sounded interesting. Cline writes in an extremely witty, smart style that endeared me to the main character from the outset.  I would not hesitate to read anything else by Cline, and having this book made into a movie is now my fondest wish. If you are a child of the 80s, if you are or were ever a gamer, if you are a geek, or if you just like well-written, action-packed, humorous novels with a solid plot and cool characters, this book is definitely worth your time.
Born in 1980 and growing up on video games, this book was just awesome. I read it in 2 days, just couldn't put it down.

I won't take a lot of space describing the story as others have done. Instead I will say that this is one of those rare stories tailor made for a specific audience and done so to perfection. It's almost as though the author read my mind when crafting a story I would have done myself if I had the writing skills. Not only did I grow up in the 80s relishing every reference to old Atari games and movie references, but I also enjoy today's modern MMO games like World of Warcraft and geek out to the latest technology whenever possible. Yes, I guess you could say its more likely a "nerd love fest" but that's part of its charm. It has enough action and intrigue to stack up to cyberpunk and techno thrillers and by adding the elements that appeal to today's gamers, Cline has a masterpiece on his hands. Please, please write a follow up novel.

So, I'm not gonna spoil anything in this review, because I think everything in the story needs to be experienced through the cannon of the story. This book is absolutely spectacular. (I am a millennial, but my father believed everything past 1990 was complete and utter crap. So I grew up appreciating the 1980's very much.) All the little references that are sprinkled through the book are perfect. All the obscure movie references, classic game references, even the fact that the story is akin to Tron, are all expertly crafted and weaved into the story. Not only did I enjoy the references, the world that Cline creates feels organic. I can totally see a world that is so bad that people feel the need to escape into a virtual reality. All I can say is that I really enjoyed this book, and am highly anticipating the expectant movie.

I listened to the audiobook of Ready Played One. At first it took some getting use to because Will Wheaton is not the greatest reader of a book I've listened to but once I got into thinking he was Wade, the main character and ultimate nerd it made sense. RPO tells the story of Wade who has a goal like most people in his world to solve a treasure hunt set by James Halliday, the richest man to have ever lived. JH was obsessed with everything 80's culture so to solve the puzzles you need to know all. Fans of 80's games, TV, movies and pop culture will love hearing all the references. Sometimes the side-tracking and background of certain 80's reference was a bit too long and took me out of the hunt which obviously I wanted to know the outcome of but I found it overall quite enjoyable and more dark then I was expecting going in.

This book was as addicting as leveling up in vanilla World of Warcraft (just a few more pages...well now I should just get to the end of the chapter...oops, did I pass the start of this chapter? just a few more pages then...). The characters are exactly what they should be: braggadocios about their abilities, as fiercely competitive as they are loyal, completely obsessed with their game, and totally insecure in "real life". If you have ever chatted online with someone, answered to your avatar's name faster than your own, or met an online friend in person, Cline paints all sides of your experience perfectly in this book. Yet, if you have never played a game in your life, you will still love it (just like if you've never been a Hobbit, you still love LoTR). Perfect, endearing, underdog story! Thanks Ernie! /Nerd-out
As someone who grew up in the 80's and a bit of a nerd myself, I absolutely loved this book. Highly recommended!!

WOW I LOVED THIS BOOK SO MUCH I CAN'T EVEN STAND IT!!! So much adventure and geekdom and emotion! I loved the world-building and the characters. Ernest Cline obviously did a lot of thorough research and carefully thought out every detail. Some parts were predictable, but I didn't mind a bit and enjoyed going along for the ride. The main character Wade is very relatable and likeable, but is also a totally flawed and realistic 18-year-old. Cline also created a really realistic view of our future and I loved how I could totally imagine how this world he thought up could be possible (not that it's a very happy world, but still). I highly, highly recommend this book and I'm going to tell everyone I know about it (heck I already started telling people before I was even halfway through). A million stars!

As a video game addict, Author, Retro Game Collector, Arcade Cabinet Builder, SciFi Geek, Former Dungeon Master, Electronics Hack, Software Developer who has written games for the Atari 2600 and cut his teeth on a C=64, and overall Nerd in every category imaginable, I felt that, for the first time, someone has finally put into a novel, exactly why I get excited about these things! I am always telling stories about the computer industry, early video games and one of my favorite stories is about Warren Robinett's Easter egg in Atari's Adventure (I was about 11 or 12 years old when my friends and I found it). Now I feel like I can finally relax, this lore is now forever preserved in the story of this book and told in a way that can bring that excitement to anyone who reads it! Thank you Ernest Cline!

I read this book in two days. I just couldn't put it down. Now I am a child of the 80's and 90's so this book was written for my generation. This book is amazing. It's awesome. I know I should be giving you some really in depth analytically correct review but I can't. I just have to say it was so good. It was fast paced. It was exciting. It was riveting. It was so cool. Ernest Cline put together the biggest menagerie of 1980's awesome geeky goodness. Buy this book and read it. Honestly, just read it. Don't have money to buy it, then go to the library and check it out. This book must be read. Ernest Clines is my hero for writing this book. So I will now tell you how I really feel, I loved this book. It was amazing... wait I said all of that. Okay so for real, buy it. You won't be disappointed.

Hands down, this books is a page turner. While a cliche term, it is no less true. The novel is especially sweet for those of us lucky enough to have enjoyed the 80's and even some of the 90's--name dropping and references galore will hit you hard with nostalgia--and for those who have played MMO's and know the way an MMO works. The action is nicely ramped, so you don't get bored but you don't get overwhelmed, either. The characters are also a major hook to this book. Immediately, you can "get a feel" for them and feel a kinship with them--provided, of course, you, too, are into the retro videogame and movie scene. I highly recommend this book to any fan of good fiction, but if you're someone able to appreciate the classics and have a taste for all things nostalgia, this is a MUST read!
This is easily the best book I have read since the hitchhikers guide to the galaxy.  I could not put it down.

I bought this book on the recommendation of Patrick Rothfuss--he suggested it on his blog.  I love that man's books, so I gave it a chance.  What a ride!  This book is mindblowingly good.  Fast paced plot and more pop culture references per second than is legal in most states.  The most incredible achievement?  All of that pop culture is completely important to the book. The Best part of the book?  The characters.  With all the importance of the pop culture madness and wonder, this book would fall on its face if I didn't care about the characters.  I couldn't stop reading--I wanted to know how this story went, and how it ended.  But I didn't want it to end!  I wanted it to go on for another 16000 pages.  Seriously.  Get this book--a new sci-fi masterpiece and classic all in one.

A new all-time favorite! It's 2044 and 18 year old Wade Watts lives in poverty in a trailer park "stack" with his abusive aunt. Like everyone else, Wade spends most of his time in the Oasis, a virtual-reality combination of the Internet and MMO games. Five years earlier, when he was dying, the creator of the Oasis, James Halliday, developed a contest, with the prize being his fortune. Success in the contest depends on the player's thorough knowledge of 1980s pop culture, which with Halliday was obsessed, having grown up in the 80s. Wade's only goal since then, is to win the contest and escape the stacks. Don't be turned off by its geekiness or if you are too young to remember the 1980s -- it's compulsively readable, with painstakingly detailed settings and a fast-paced plot.

Ready Player One is a romping fun exploration of all things geeky. It is largely well-written, and easy to rip through in a day. Its only shortcomings are that it is somewhat shallow -- there is not as much inventive world creation as in Snow Crash, for example, but the plot progression is better. It is also predictable -- it's the kind of book you read to see how it unfolds, not to see what happens, you can guess that from the back of the book. It leans heavily on the video-game/movie side of geek-hood, with fewer references to scifi/fantasy books, music, and other geeky pursuits. This book is ideal for geeks who fondly remember the 80s, and who want a fun and easy read. It will not satisfy those who are looking for fine literature, plot-twists, or in-depth world creation.

This was my first one by Ernest Cline, and I'll admit I enjoyed it thoroughly despite all of its whimsical absurdity. The entire novel is basically a nostalgic homage to 80's pop culture mixed with new age MMORGS. I thought the idea of the idea of the Oasis harboring the most legitimate form of currency in a futuristic society was very clever. It's just page turning fun, and I though it was very cool. I also thought it was funny that the climax entailed everybody jumping in for a huge video game binge and blacking out the windows. I love this book, but I also suspect I'm the precise demographic that was being targeted. Also loved some of the specific references, haven't thought about some of the 80's stuff in decades. Very humorous and fun read if not taken too seriously.

This is by far the geekiest, nerdiest book I've ever read. That being said, it was completely satisfying. I really loved this book. Granted, I had no clue about many of the references in it, the book was still really easy to keep up with and kept a good pace. I think it might have been better if the author had included more main stream references when it came to the video games included in the hunt for the easter egg, but despite the lack of these references, I still found the entire story very enjoyable. I would definitely  recommend this to anyone with a geek/nerd background, especially  gamers who grew up in the 80's - I think they would really appreciate this book. Overall I really enjoyed this book and I can't wait to see how Spielberg portrays it in the movie.

Ready Player One was a book that I always wanted to read but always seemed to get bumped by other titles. After finishing the novel last week, I don't know why I waited so long. The world that Cline creates is one out of a video game fans dreams with virtual reality worlds and haptic feedback body suits. 90% of the game takes place in the virtual world called Oasis as the players go on a huge quest with 80's trivia and geek culture moments that culminates in someone winning the right to rule the Oasis. If it sounds overly nerdy, that' because it is, and it's wonderful for it. If you're looking for something different that pays homage to many video games, 80's movies, and Saturday Morning Cartoons, look no further, this is a hit book that you'll enjoy reading.

I absolutely loved this book. While it is technically centered around teenagers in an evolved society, it never seemed like it was your typical YA dystopian society novel. I loved the 80's references. I loved the pace of the book. This was a can't put it down book for me. I loved the fact that it did not seem to follow any other formula than it's own. The characters are all well defined. Most characters are likeable. I was transported to this futuristic world. Anyone that is a gamer would more than likely really relate to this book. You want to become a part of the competition and wish that something like this would happen in reality. I HIGHLY recommend this book to everyone! The story is so good that most non-readers I have recommended it to loved it.

I cannot recommend this novel enough for anyone who has ever picked up a controller and been swept away by a videogame. This is escapist literature at it's finest level, yet it is grounded in a poignant reality much bleaker than the mundane world with which we are familiar. Children of the 1980's hearken, for this otherworldly masterpiece is the perfect addendum to that greatest of all decades, when geeks were nerds, when movies were still grand, and when an extra life cost a mere quarter. This book brings back all of the magic of that seminal decade, though it is set in a dark, dystopian future not too far-flung from where we find ourselves now. Such a glorious novel, one that makes me weep for the past while filling me with hope for the future.

This was a GREAT book!  Ready Player One is the story of a loner high school student in the not too distant future trying to win one of the world's biggest ever video game contests. (Well, video game isn't really the best description - it's more like Sim City + Facebook + the Internet turned to life and then some.)  The book relies heavily on 80's references and pop culture, which turned what could have been a depressing dystopian fiction book into a colorful Rubik Cube of a story.  I have no clue why I waited so long to read this - I think something about the cover turned me off. Somehow my brain saw the cover and title and assumed this was about a piano player or something.  Nope.  Ready Player One is pure fun future fiction of be best quality.

In terms of sheer entertainment value, Ready Player One gets 5 starts, but it loses a point because the writing itself is only okay, and there were a few places where I thought things could have been explained or foreshadowed a little bit better. But these are minor grievances for a book that kept me up late reading and thinking about its worlds and characters all day long, eager to get back to the story and find out what happens next. If you grew up in the 80s, even if you aren't a gamer (I'm not), you'll appreciate the references to old Atari games (Adventure being chief among them) and classic 80s movies. The story is well paced and keeps you guessing until the end. Extremely creative, well thought out, and unlike anything I have ever read.

As as 80's baby who played the same video games and watched the same movies and TV shows name checked throughout this book, it was like train-spotting all my influences I had growing up. Constant "oh yeah, I remember that game" and "oh yeah, I remember that scene" as I was reading. Ernest Cline puts together an MMO game world reminiscent of WoW as a backdrop to a winner gets all / good vs evil plot which had me tear through his book within a week. Characters are well thought out and relatable to the type of culture being presented. The world in and of itself I felt was also a character which kept pulling me in wondering what surprise would be next. I'm not quite sure how he would do it, but it'd be great if he wrote a sequel.

I know it's already been said before, but this is like The Matrix meets Willy Wonka with a bit of National Treasure thrown in.  As a geeky gen x'er that also grew up in the 80s, you can't help but find yourself nostalgic for all of the pop culture references and trivia crammed in this little book. That aside, it's a fun read and very well paced.  The only negative I'd give relates to the cause and effect aspects of the declining world and the OASIS itself. Without giving any spoilers, I don't believe the author addressed the reality that much of the misery experienced in the real world was likely a direct effect of the distraction brought on by the virtual world. Nonetheless, it was a great and fun adventure that I'd enjoy reading again.

My review is 5 stars because (A) I have experience in an MMO (Everquest and World of Warcraft) and (B) I was alive and devouring the 80s.  If you do not meet those two criteria, you may enjoy the book but it may be lost on you if you cant really relate to being totally immersed in an online alternate universe.  In particular, you may struggle with how people can form such strong bonds with people they have never met nor really know in real life (RL).  That said, if you meet the criteria, you are going to love the book.  It is an easy read and will take you traipsing through your past experiences in an on line culture.  Even better if you actually fell in love with someone as their avatar and you hooked up and lived happily ever after ;-)

An expertly crafted and impossibly fun adventure into the near future.  This book will be an instant favorite of any child of the 80s, geek, nerd, dork, dweeb, gamer, techie, or breathing person.  Truly one of my favorite reads in a very long time.  I smiled and laughed almost the entire way through.  The story was clever, packed full of pop-culture references, and it continuously surprised and excited.  The setups were interesting and the payoffs satisfying.  Cline did a masterful job of making you care not only for the Wade Watts, but also for the several peripheral characters with which he interacts.  Also, the book is a very fast read despite its almost 400 pages, mostly because I simply couldn't put it down.  I highly recommend it!
I have read this book 4 times since its release. Buy it and read it. You won't be able to put it down.

I used to be one of those people who read a book a day, literally. I was that way for years...But life changed and things changed and I find it hard to fit in more than a few books a year. I read this in one day. It was good enough and so strongly appealed to my geeky, sci-fi-loving heart that I put everything else on hold. (Aka I was totally irresponsible because I "needed" to keep reading.) The ideas are great, the plot is well laid out, and the writing is engaging (whether making me laugh or making me cringe). If there's even a little geek in your soul, feed it this most excellent book!

Being a gamer since I was a kids and my parents bought me Zork and Pong when they came out.  I got every reference that was in the book.  It just seemed to me that story was slowed down as the book tried to force almost every reference in the story. Every time hr did something in the story he had to reference and explain what it was.  He couldn't just put on a jacket he had to put on "a red leather jacket with zippers like the jacket that Michael Jackson wore in the video Beat it" That is what made to story tedious.  Something interesting what be happening then in the middle a reference and explanation of something that felt forced . As if to say "look how clever i am."  for me to the point that it got on the way of story telling.

Do you like cyberpunk but think The Matrix and its tropes are a little "2edgey4u?" Did you think Sword Art Online was a wonderful show but too depressing? Are you a fan of classic D&D;, old school video games, and/or 80s trivia? Then gather your d20s, power on your Commodore 64, and get some arcard tokens in your pocket because Ready Play One is the novel for you!!  I got this book as part of the February Loot Crate and loved every page of it.  I'm a huge nerd and loved all the cameos and asides.  It's like Roger Rabbit and Wreck-it Ralph but with all kinds of nerdy cameos!  There's Monty Python, 1st Edition D&D;, Japanese tokusatsu, anime, cartoons, 80s pop culture and more.  Give this book a read.  You won't be sorry!

It has been almost a year since I have read this, and it still sticks with me.  While I do believe this to be an incredible book, one caveat is that you really must be an 80's nerd to truly get it.  It is littered with video game, music and movie references that will force you to dig deep down into your cerebrum to recognize.  For those of you who aren't verse in 80's culture, much of this book will fall flat.  The overall story is still so absorbing that I think it's enjoyable without this knowledge, I believe it will suffer some.  Give it a try though, because this is one of the true greats of the neo-dystopian rage that is taking over (this is not one of the numerous "teen" ones out there, but a genuine good read).

I read this book about two years ago and had a blast the first time.  It was a serious trip down memory lane for me and, while I may not have gotten every single reference in the book, I think I got most of them and could relate with everything. It's a great ride, it's a fun read, and quite frankly both times I've read this book I've had a hard time putting it down. The characters are all likable, The story moves at a great pace, and the writing pulls you in as though a good friend were telling you a story you couldn't wait to hear the end of. If you lived through the 80s as a teenager or of an age there about, this book is bound to be a great thrill for you and a whole lot of fun.  I just hope they don't screw up the movie!

I absolutely loved this book.  I read tons of YA books as a high school teacher.  Many of the books I read seem to only appeal to other teachers, or the age groups we teach.  This book, however, would appeal to many different groups.  Whether you are a fan of the 80's, spent a great deal of your childhood or adolescence in the 1980's, are a current gamer, a former gamer, the parent of a gamer...the list is endless.  I know some reviewers did not like the constant references to 80's pop culture, or the explanations that went along with those references, but that is part of what kept me so enthralled.  There aren't very many books that a parent and teen can read, enjoy, and discuss together.  This is definitely one of them.

I LOVE this book! I got most of the pop culture references very quickly,and didn't have much trouble following the plot. Great characters and settings too. One thing in the book that took me by surprise was the ending, which I won't spoil for you if you haven't read the book. My favorite part was learning about fictional game creator James Haliday and how he created the virtual reality known as the OASIS. If you don't understand some of the video game terms that are used in this book, don't worry! Most of them are explained as they come up in the book. The tech vocab shouldn't stop you from reading this book. Overall, Ready Player One is one of the best books I have read in a long time, and I highly recommend it.

Okay, I loved this book and am certainly one of the people this book was written for.  I still play old adventure games, 80s music, and was an early BBS user - I had an atari 2600 when I was a kid and played it a lot - my dad was an electrical engineer and I had The Holy Grail memorized before I started high school(and I'm a chick) - I was never AS into the movies and TV of the 80s as some of the characters in this book - but many of them are still in my head as classics.  This is a very unique and fun book and I am so happy one of my friends (who shares my love of classic video games) recommended it to me.  I listened to it on audio read by Wil Wheaton which was a little surreal but also really fun as well.

This work of fiiction was a delight to read.  It cleverly integrated references to movies and games of the 80's with an exciting quest adventure, set in the backdrop of a touching personal story.  My husband and I each owned one of the first Atari game systems, had an Apple II primarily to play games on, saw all of the popular movies of the 80's, and knew where to play an arcade game at the mall.  This book was written exactly for us, but I am betting if you are aware of any of these enthusiasms, you'll be hooked as well.  We each read the book in under 3 days and then bought copies for friends.  Very appropriate for young adults as well, no sex, minimal violence and a few good life lessons along the way.

I loved this book. Cline outdid himself I think I read this book in less than two days. I might have even called in sick at work just to finish it.  If you loved Atari, Back to the Future, Ferris Bueller and all 80's science fiction including Star Wars then you have to read this. Not only does this book bring a whole new science fiction world into play but Ready Player One should be put on a pedestal and celebrated. Phillip K. Dick and Kurt Vonnegut would be proud. This was easily the best book I have read in years. I put this ahead of Pullitzer Prize winner Devil in the Grove (Non-Fiction) by Gilbert King. Think John Hughes meets Fanboys (written by Cline I might add) and future that is very possible!

This is the first book I've ever read that made me feel obligated to give it a 5 star review on Amazon. I've read many MANY books in my 21 years, but this is honestly the best I've ever read. Ernest Cline writes with a style that is at once extremely witty, yet easily understood and enjoyed. He speaks with a voice that we all wish we could speak with. Who knew that video games (of all things) could be such a human expression of our collective experiences? Many books claim to be a "page-turner". Ready Player One actually IS. I actually read a little of this book while driving 75mph down the interstate. Yes. You read that correctly. If that isn't the mark of a great read, I don't know what is.

Cline's Ready Player One (RPO) is an interesting read.  It picks up on the economic crisis, projecting a long downward slide from it, while maintaining the same level of technological development as a premise.  Cline's prose is clever and not overly flowery, although at times the plot line treads the realm of cliche (in a sense, the book mirrors the plot line of Goonies, although both works basically take up the Campbellian "hero's journey").  The love of and references to eighties pop culture was a pleasant nod to a lot of readers that seem to have grown up with a sense of wonder brought about by eighties technological optimism (WarGames and Robocop aside).  I think it's a heck of a debut novel.

Ready Player One is a book that I couldn't stop reading. Like a video game that can hold your attention for hours on end you just have to keep going. When you have to sleep and save your place you can only dream about returning to the vivid world that the book creates to learn the rest of what happens to Parzival and his friends. From beginning to end this book is engaging, laugh out loud funny and moving in all of the ways that you want a book to be. Now that I've left the world of the Oasis by finishing the book, however, I find that I really want to go back. Well written and a nostalgic romp through the classic times that many of us quite enjoyed. Pick up this book today...you won't regret it!

I listened to this book on a recent car trip.  Both Wil Wheaton's reading and the words themselves drew me into the story.  The descriptions and action were so vivid that it was like watching a mental movie rather than listening to an audiobook. I am not a geek.  My brother played D&D; and tried to get me to play but I didn't have the patience to read the guidebooks and understand the rules. And I grew up in the 70's, but the cultural references reminded me of the time. Like the multi-layered puzzles in the story, the story is multi-layered exploring themes of culture, technology, individuals vs corporations, what is reality?, what is friendship?  There is alot to discuss here and think about.

This was a fun book to read. Was the story predictable? absolutely. Was there too many specific references to video games, 80's TV and entertainment? Yes, but does that make it a bad book? Not on your life. If you like action and adventure and 80's arcade games you will enjoy this one. I'm not giving the story 5 stars because the villain of the story kind of just fizzled out at the end. This could actually be made into a pretty cool movie if they can recreate the OASIS on film. With special effects these days it should be possible and would be great escapism for the movie goer. I also, liked the message of the story at the end. If you're looking for something fun to ready pick this one up.
I'm not a gamer at all, so picking up this book was risky for me. It was absolutely phenomenal.

I gave this book 4 stars but could easily give it 5 if a few things had been different. It took me a while to get sucked into the book but once I did there were nights I lost track of time or didn't want to stop reading. The book has a great concept and pretty well written, and had great humor this book could easily keep the interest of people age 13-25 it wasn't dumbed down or overly sophisticated. The only thing I wish was that some of the detail based sections weren't so long I love being able to pictures an environment but I found myself skipping sentences because they seemed to ramble or over explain but it didn't deter me from reading further I had to know WHO WOULD FIND THE EGG!

as someone born in 1980 who was lucky enough to have parents that were into videogames before I was even born, this book is a like taking a trip back through some of the happiest moments in my life.  its like spending time with a lifelong friend and a reminder of all the friends ive had over the years who shared these memories with me.  the author has a way of inviting you into his world with his words and once you are there, you never want to leave.  I cant even begin to guess how many more times I will read this book...it will have to be dozens.  ive never felt so happy at the end of a book and so sad that its over.  I am in awe...and this book will be a part of my life forever.

Amazing. At the end of the day, that's the only word I need to say about Ready Player One to be honest. I don't even need to go any further in detail. This book is completely utterly amazing. But I can't just leave my review as just that... okay one more time AMAZING. Everyone really needs to get this book now, order it on Amazon, or stop by a book store. The world building, the OASIS, everything is just completely great. Makes you think about yourself inside the story, in this virtual world. After I finished reading this book, I just sat there hugging it like a love sick teenager. But I am not ashamed at all. If I could give it a higher rating I would. So go pick it up. The End.

One of the best books I've read this year.  A friend told me I would like it and I love it!  If you grew up in the 80's or even the 90's you might find that this story strikes a cord with you.  I don't want to tell you much, as not to ruin it, but let's just say that this story takes place in the future.  A terrible future where most people live in stacks and everyone spends the majority of their time in a virtual reality world.  The creator of this world, who was a billionaire, died and left the ultimate easter egg in the virtual world.  People for the past decade have been hunting for it - until a young kid finds him self in the middle of the game to end all games.  READ THIS!

This is not my normal kind of book. It was suggested to me by a friend. I didn't read it rather I listened to the Audio version that is narrated by Will Wheaton. I have to say this was one of the most amazing stories I've ever come across. I am a big nerd and gamer and this book recalled some good memories. While I am a little young to get all of the 80's references the picture it painted didn't require me to know everything. You will totally fall for all the characters and you will be very sad once the book is over. If your looking for a good read this book I recommend highly. And as a side note if you listen to it Will brings life to these characters like you wouldn't imagine.

I received this book as an advanced copy and I loved it.  I just thoroughly enjoyed the amazing, thrilling journey of this story and its ideas.  There is a lot to think about in this book--possibilities that aren't too far fetched given our current state of the world and technology--and also a lot over which to reminisce.  This book was fun, engaging and wildly imaginative.  I'm really looking forward to more from this author and am begging my husband to read Ready Player One because he is such an 80's and tech geek/freak.  Then we can talk about the book together experience some of the fun again.

It's entertaining, and brings me back to the brink of adulthood.  I'm into it.  Is it the greatest novel ever?  No.  Will it transport you to the edge between a former reality and a possibly hideous future?  Yes.  Relax into it, and enjoy.  I've read it through once, and listened to the audio book read by Will Weaton twice on my commute to work.  Like all of us, the main character is part hero, part flawed and often uncertain of himself.  It's sci-fi, but very relatable if you were on planet earth in the 80's and grew up with tech.  I look forward to his next book, and to this one becoming a movie.  Fast forward 20 years... this will be a cult classic like Hitchhiker's Guide.

This gamer of a certain age felt right at home with the cultural references sown throughout this book. You could say this was aimed at a fairly small demograghic of older gamers but I think it crosses over into an area that a lot of people would enjoy. Although it was rare for me not to recognize the many many references to gaming and 80's culture, I don't think it would deter anyone younger from enjoying this book. It certain would help to be a gamer of some type, but again, I don't think it would be a deal breaker. The characters and near future plot are believeable and intriguing. I look forward to seeing more from this author, not something I say too often these days.
This book is so much fun and an incredibly fast read. If you like the 80s, this is for you!

Very well written, and right in my wheelhouse, too.  The premise manages to frame itself so that the reader can fully embrace the setting - which allows for unlimited references to 80's sci-fi, fantasy, video games, and music - with limited suspension of disbelief (almost certainly a lesser degree of suspension required for the majority of the material being referenced).  The main character is interesting enough to be engaging, but nondescript enough to allow the reader to easily project themselves in his place.  This work has such a rare mix of innovation, artistry, and nostalgic hook that I'd be surprised if we don't eventually end up with a film adaptation.

I don't enjoy video games, I am on a needs-to-know basis with my laptop, and I don't (usually) enjoy science fiction. Having stated those facts I want to say I absolutely loved this book. The pace, originality, and just over-arching draw of the characters and plot drew me in and forced me to finish it in 2 days. I normally am a historical fiction nerd- and those books don't generally move quickly- this one barely gives you a breath to put it down. This book is for anyone- to those who will gleefully enjoy all 80s references (I being 5 years younger than the Halliday character got most) to those younger ones into virtual reality gaming. Do not pass this one up.

I don't know, maybe I'm just at that stage in my life where the message in the book really resonated with me but without the superb writing I don't think it would have ever happened. To not spoil any of the content, it is suffice to say the message that the book has about escaping to another world and abandoning reality, its repercussions, and the parallel you can draw to the real world was enlightening. Can't say it changed my life yet because I just finished it, but we will see. Anyway its a must read, and I am really picky about what I read too. Great plot delivered with care, devotion, and awesomeness is what this book is all about, buy it and read it.

I suppose one might object to a book that so clearly defines good versus bad, but in a book that is half video game, it is a necessary gambit. While white and black have no shadows, the characters are half shadow themselves-- avatars, emails, chat room denizens as well as flesh and blood. Much of this book is about identity, and finding connections. Give this to a young teen or an adult, and both will devour it. You know how boring it is to watch someone else play a video game? Well, reading about it in Ready Player One is a thrill. Nice. The 80's references are fun too. The setting is dystopian and grim, but the tone of the book is not. An enjoyable read.

I received this book as part of a Loot Crate. I can safely say, it was the only thing in the crate that I loved. It made the cost worth it. I typically don't fly through books, I'll read a chapter or two, put it down, and pick it back up a few days later. I read this book in two days, and only because I started on it late one evening. If I had started it early in the day, I'd have read it cover to cover. If you like pop culture stuff, especially 80's stuff, you are doing yourself a disservice by not having read this already. You can read a summary anywhere, so I won't go into all of that. I'm just going to say to buy this book now and clear your schedule.

This book is perfect for any child of the 80's.  I was born in 1975, so the Reagan years were an important period of influence on my upbringing.  Ernest Cline has created a joyous celebration of 1980s pop culture with Ready Player One.  Video games, music, movies, cartoons, etc. are all touched upon in the process of telling an epic save-the-world story.  The amount of allusions to other media is positively dizzying.  However, the story and characters are strong enough that, even if you didn't come of age around the time Cline did, there is still a lot to love here.  But if you were born between 1970 and 1980, I'd say the journey will be even sweeter.

I really enjoyed this book read by Wil Wheaton. It is packed with all of the stuff I love from my childhood and a few factoids that I didn't know from my childhood. Video games and pop culture from the 80s makes this read really awesome. It's like Ernest Cline knew what I was into growing up. I even share the same initials as one of the main characters: JDH. How weird and cool is that?! Bonus is that it's being made into a movie. I hope that's as entertaining as this book. The only reason I gave it four out of five stars is that there is a slight "cheese factor" that took me out of the book some, but I could overlook it because it's awesome overall.

When I was a young child, less than twelve years old, I read a book named epic (épico in my native language, which is portuguese) . I was mesmerized by the universe, in which a a society settled in a new world was all centered around a fantasy game( which had the same name of the book) . Initially the character has the goal of killing a dragon and,therefore, seizing all its treasure, which would grant  him and all his friends a comfortable life. However, the story unveils a much deeper and broader problem the character has to solve. This book, which I loved so much, is a a child of the great and innovative writing and storytelling that is this book.

This is an absolutely addictive world. As soon as i picked it up I lost myself in the book, I never wanted to stop reading it. Sadly real life kept pulling me out of it forcing me to read it over the course of about two and a half weeks. I am in love with all of this and I found myself satisfied with how it ended. If this is his first published work I'm definitely going to have to check out all of his other stuff. I couldn't help but devour every second and allow it to melt into my mind, every action in this book will be staying with me in my head for years to come and i'll be reading it again and again once i've gone through the rest of my books.

I just can't express completely how fun this book was to read.  This book is not just a nostalgia piece, it was practically a celebration and revival of much of my childhood.  But, even that isn't totally fair.  Put aside all the 80's references to movies and videogames, and you are STILL left with a great adventure that is well told, funny, and very exciting.  Often times I couldn't put this book down without reading at least 3 chapters at a time.  If you have any appreciation at all for vintage 80's games and culture AND/OR want to read a great exciting adventure/quest novel, look no further.  Ready Yourself, Player One, and pick this book up.

I read this book in less than two days which is rare for me. It pulled me in from the first page and the world was well fleshed out.  I had a few minor qualms with the book. The biggest is that the plotting was a little predictable.  I always felt a step or two a head of the characters. While I didn't always know all the specifics that each of the pieces were going to play into the end game, I certainly saw how they were being aligned earlier than the author intended and was able to make a pretty good guess at their eventual role.  That said, the book was such a pleasure to read and moved at such an enjoyable pace that I didn't really mind.

I absolutely adored this audiobook version of Ready Player One. Wil Wheaton does a fantastic job narrating this book and is such a great match for the voice of the main character Wade Watts. I'm a totally nerdy gal, and I loved all of the 1980s music, film, and video game references. The story arch and flow were great, and the concept is a bit of sci-fi that doesn't seem like that doesn't require too much suspending of disbelief. Sure you could nit pick at little inconsistencies, but who cares! It's a fun ride, and great read. If you love sci-fi, and above all video games, this is perfect for a road trip or tooling around in your car.

This was an incredible book. There is a lot that it tries to say, and it does so in a fun and easy way. It shows the dangers of corporate greed, how big businesses don't play by the rules, and how the internet can be a life consuming distraction from reality. But possibly my favorite point, is showing that just because you talk to someone online, does not make them any less real. The story is great, with good pacing. The characters are memorable. and the entire thing is a nostalgia trip from the 80's. This has become one of my favorite books of all time, and I am truly happy to see authors be able to provide this level of writing.

What a great book. While it is mainly a love letter to nerds, geeks, and the '80's, at the same time it sets forth a plausible scenario of the future, both technologically and domestically. I was unsure how much I would like a book largely set inside a future VR game, but it works because the game actions have a very profound effect in the characters' real world. I listened to this through Audible, narrated by Will Wheaton. He does an amazing job and has a great voice for this kind of work. It became pretty "meta" when he ended up reading a few passages that referenced Star Trek:Next Generation. I thoroughly enjoyed it.

A great combination of story plot and tight writing.  An additional plus for me was to "re-live" the days of the first easter eggs, old video games and systems, big hair bands, etc. Absolutely TONS of 80's references that made me wax nostalgic and annoy my wife with stories of "the old days".  Cline also runs an excellent cautionary subtext of what might happen if society moves to valuing electronic interactions over physical, but doesn't get preachy about it.  I also enjoyed the (possibly imagined!) parallels betwwen IOI and what Microsoft might finally turn into.  I've not read Cline before but can't wait for his next effort!
Its been a long time since I didn't want a book to end.  This was so much fun to read!

On some levels Ready Player One isn't the most innovative of books. The basic setup of the plot is similar to stories you've undoubtedly read before. But what makes this book cool is the depth and creativity of the setting. If you love books with immersive settings that are grand in scale and that make sense and that permeate the whole novel, then you'll love this book. Even if you don't know all of the 80s games and music and movies that are referenced, you'll still have a blast. I only recognized a small fraction of the references myself and I still stayed up late two nights in a row in order to finish this wonderful book.

Well, like a lot of people, I actually received my copy of Ready Player One in my Loot Crate subscription. Although I tend to love all books with words in them, very few actually captivate me to the extinct of keeping it in my library forever. This book will forever hold a place on my shelves. I couldn't put the book down, and ended up reading it all within two days. I did have to eat and sleep. I was born in the late 80s, so while I didn't understand every reference, I know I will have to study up on everything from that era now to get a deeper understanding and feel like I might actually have a chance of finding the egg.

If you grew up playing video games on an Apple II or an Atari console, this book will definitely appeal a lot to you. It's a hyper kinetic cyberpunk novel set in a non so-distant but Orwellian future, and whith constant reference to the 80s-90s pop culture. The plot is well crafted, and the whole book is built very much as a video game itself: various levels, each composed of on-going quests and mini-games and each finishing by a battle with a big boss. The characters are well constructed, and the narrative style is reminiscent of Gibson, Stephenson and of some classic SF authors such as Bradbury or Vonnegut. Overall a great book with a fast-paced and entertaining storyline!

A lot has been made of the fact that this book steeps itself in 80's pop-culture nostalgia.  While that is true, and folks who were around long enough to remember that stuff will get an extra level of enjoyment out of it, I think the story stands on its own.  The 80's references are explained well enough so that the story is plenty understandable, even if the reader was not previously familiar with them.  And the vision of the future that the story presents is an fascinating and somewhat plausible one, in my opinion.  I think anyone who enjoys science fiction will enjoy this book, whether they remember the 80's or not.

This book was recommended to me by a fellow commuter. She said it had so much 80's pop culture goodness. It does. I had to rewatch War games after starting it. I love all the references and it feed my inner geek girl. Not to mention, it was written in such a way that kept me on the edge of my seat,  I wanted to finish it all at once, but I wanted to savor it too! I hope to find another just like it now that I'm done and really hope it makes it to the movie phase, though all the money they will have to spend to use all of the copywrite items in the book will cost a bundle, unless they become corp sponsers.. hrrrrm.

Ready Player one is the best, most entertaining, fun books I've read in the last five years. If you're my age (grew up in the late seventies and the eighties), even if you're not a fan of sci-fi, you may enjoy this book. It's built on and references the movies, television, music (including a very nice homage to Rush), and video games we grew up watching and playing. And, on top of all of that fun, the plot was solid and the writing good. I'm just going to stop here, because all I'll end up doing is gush about how wonderful I think this book is, and I think I've adequately conveyed that sentiment at this point.

I read all the time. In fact in the past month I've read around 20 books. Some good, some bad but nothing that was quite as fun as this one. The plot was just so good, and refreshing! Don't get me wrong, you know where the book is going the entire time but you're just having so much fun with the characters you don't care. I started out liking this book and ended up loving it. If you've ever played an old game you'll appreciate all the old references and get hit hard with nostalgia. Joust! Hadn't thought about that game in forever. Really well written and edited, can't say enough great things about the book.

I can fully understand why this book is receiving so many five-star reviews. It is positively brimming with 70’s and 80’s classic pop culture, not to mention loads of action and adventure! You don’t have to be a geek to enjoy this story: I was captivated from the word go and spent every spare minute I had immersed in this futuristic fantasy game; wishing I could have my own avatar with which to explore and experience the OASIS. I can only imagine the amount of time, research and plotting that went into creating this absolutely unforgettable novel.  In the right hands, this can be made into an epic movie!

This book might be the best book you read all year, possibly the best book you read all decade.  It's just your typical cyberpunk coming of age love story mystery adventure about online gaming.  The plot is tightly constructed and the story makes you laugh, cry and cheer.  However, the best part of the book is how it weaves and integrates Generation X geek culture throughout the story.  There were major references to my favorite games, video games, anime, books and movies throughout the book.  Seriously, this book was written for uber-nerds like me and it was almost like I had written the words myself.

Cline has produced an instant hit! This one is brilliant. The pace and plot are tempo'd perfectly to keep you interested and reading and yearning for more, but not too fast that he would gloss over the important elements. The story and design of the world is unique and new. It is a perfect 80's cult throwback, with modern elements. Most importantly it does not require you to be a huge 80's brainbox or geek to enjoy this one. It has all the wit and humor, all of the fun adventure and drama. It is the next book that you should be reading. Go on, stop searching now and get this book. Ready Player One.

I found this book being hyped at Comic Con International.  I put it on my wish list and bought it from Amazon when it became available.  I am not a gamer, I think I played pac-man a couple times and I am not a "fat, virgin, high school boy" that some reviewers indicate this book was written for.  I am a 48 year old woman and I really enjoyed the escape and simplicity of this sci-fi/fantasy book.  Ernest Cline will be in town for a book signing and I will be there in line to see him.  I highly recommend this book.

I absolutely loved this book!!! Futuristic and very close to what our world might become. Virtual Reality is the main focus in the book. Everyone is logged in, to  the virtual reality "OASIS" to escape the lousy world. The maker of this " OASIS" dies and leaves all his billions hidden in this virtual reality. Whom ever finds the three keys wins the game!! You will route for the main characters, to beat the bad guys and win !! The " OASIS IS HUGE AND ANYTHING IS POSSIBLE, even Ultra Man!!! This book would make an awesome movie! I wish I could produce it!! Loved it did not want it to end!!!!!

I have a book hangover in the best possible way. I definitely don't self identify as someone who is into video games or 80's pop culture (which this book is full of) but after picking up Ready Player One I couldn't put it down. The world that Ernest Cline has created comes to life and sucks you in as easily as if you were slouched on the couch watching a tv show. This book just felt effortless. I never had to will myself to pick it back up again. Instead, I had to will myself to put it down. The writing and quick plot line made me want to devour more and more until suddenly... it was done.

I decided to write a review for this book because as a child of the 1980s and a GenX geek I feel like I am it's target audience. I have to give it my highest recommendation. This was exactly the book I was waiting for, but just didn't know it. I can understand if some people might not understand every geek reference in the book, but Cline does a great job filling you in and keeping you in the inner circle. There's a great adventure waiting for those whoe've yet to read this one, I just wish there were more stories in this universe already written so I could dive into the next installment.

This is the most fun i've ever had reading a book.  I was so genuinely happy as i read it that i worried about my own sanity.  At first i had no interest in it because it seemed to be a lame videogame related sci fi story rather than a hardcore cyberpunk story, but after accidentally posting its cover on a cyberpunk forum not realizing what it was, i was moved to give it a shot when i read the comments left regarding it.  I got it for a steal with amazon prime,  but its so good im gonna rebuy it in hardcover or at least paperback if i have to.  And if i lose that copy, ill buy it again.

Preordered this on Monday, started it on Tuesday, finished it on Thursday. Loved every page. It's like this book sprang from the trivia inside my own head. If the words "beta capsule" or Tranzor-Z mean anything to you... if you can close your eyes and picture the covers to specific 1st-edition D&D; modules in your head... if you can name the arcade game featured in the music video for the Rush song "Subdivisions"... this book is for you. Packed with equal amounts of cyberpunky action and geektastic nostalgia.

But there are themes and messages, especially in the last line of the book, that really damage the story.  It celebrates geek culture throughout but also has a tendency to look down on the parts of it the writer doesn't understand.  A book so reliant on the things geeks love should not take such a stance against certain aspects.  Loved the ideas and the references and the competition/egg hunt.  But it didn't quite make it to perfection thanks to an attempt to push an anti-virtual agenda.  Note that I would rate this a 3.5 out of 5, not a 3, but .5 ratings are not possible on Amazon.

I liked this book a lot. My sister's boyfriend recommended it and I was really glad he did. The descriptions of all the old video games were kind of like a trip down memory lane and at some points I felt like I was actually in the old arcades of my youth.The book is kind of like a non-stop description of video games and movies with just enough plot and action thrown in to work but that is part of why I liked it. the descriptive nature of it kind of made me space out into daydreams of the old games. I really recommend this to people who grew up in the days when arcades still existed.

All the reviews about this book being a captivating read are more than true. The idea of being able to live in a virtual world is an interesting concept, and who wouldn't want to root for the underdog main character? However, given that the book is centered around a lot of 80's references, these references might lose their magic for those who are not familiar with them. It definitely makes things a lot more enjoyable if you understand them, but I found that it didn't matter much even if you didn't understand them. The characters and the story were enough to help me turn the pages.

Though I wasn't drawn into the D&D;/gaming craze, being a child of the 80s and someone regularly nostalgic for 80s music,  movies, and shows, I really enjoyed this. I was recommended this book by so many people that I bought and read the ebook without any idea what it was about. When I finished reading, I quite literally described it someone as Willy Wonka for the MMO/social media age... then I saw a copy of the physical book and had to smile - perfect review USA Today  :)  If like me, you grew up in the 80s, you really need to read this. Quick, easy, and an enjoyable read.

One of the best books I've read in a while. I couldn't put this one down. Well I couldn't turn it off since it was the audio version. Do you love the 80's movies, video games, music, movies? Even if you don't I think you will still love it, I couldn't get enough. I listen to the whole thing in one sitting. I was up till noon the next day and I've never done that with a book before. Also, Wil Wheaton does a great job as a narrator. I got sucked in and didn't want it to end. I believe that a movie is in the works as well which will rock. I love this book! Read it! Do it!

This is the first book in quite a while that I literally could not stand to put down. I read the whole thing in a day! The main characters are intriguing and likeable despite their flaws, and you really care what happens to them in the end. All the 80s references are just plain fun! But you don't need to be an 80s expert to read the book. I didn't catch all the references either, but it didn't detract at all from the plot. This story is inventive and refreshing--a lighter, fun read when you're looking for something entertaining but still with a little bit of substance.

If you grew up in the 80's and played the games of the time and learned all about Computers on the monster consoles and played with the joystick games in the Arcade then this book may be for you. If you're too young to know what an Arcade is then you may want to keep browsing. This book brings aspects of MMORPG to life with the world inside the game taking the place of the despair of reality for it's players and follows the quest for fortune and fame. This was a quick read though I was a little disappointed in the ending I would read it again for many years to come.

I received this in my Loot Crate and was at first disappointed I received a book, not a big reader.  However after I decided to give it a try and see what it was about (I must have been living under a rock since this came out in 2011)  I LOVE IT. I didn't want to put the book down.  I read it in three sitting over 2 days.  Give it a try if you like the any of the following, 80s pop culture, video games, dystopian fiction.  I would describe it as Willy Wonka meets Hunger Games (in a video game) all set in a future world with poor resources and government corruption.

Once in a great while something really new and memorable comes along ! Once again, I got the audio version and listened while driving the lost highway. The central character is easy to like and the story moves along briskly . I'm more psychically fused with the 70's than the 80's but that didn't interfere with appreciating the detailed description of the myriad forms cultural minutiae from the Gen X Decade. There isn't much physical description of Wade Watts but one gets to know his avatar very well. This is a fun read . Don't wait for the inevitable movie version.

For video gamers lovers like me, it was a fantastic journey! If you were a teen in the 80s, it will be even better, since  it's full of pop references that are perfectly fit in the story by the author. As a future dystopia, it's very reasonable and the main plot is all fun. The backbone story sustains a serious critical analysis of the challenge that our virtual society is facing right now, when confronted with the "disease of our century", i.e. scape of the reality. If you like unpretentious, but honest and solid Sci-Fi, like me, I'm sure it will be quite a ride!

Old school gamers like myself will love the walk down memory chip lane.  Qbert, Joust, the Commodore 64 - really?  How much fun is that?  I read this as part of a class activity (I am a teacher) with two other sophomore boys and they enjoyed the story as well.  We did have to spend part of a class finding a Joust emulator online so they could better visualize the challenges the character faces - but that just added to the fun.  The virtual and real world this author creates is very satisfying and provides the perfect backdrop for this futuristic action adventure.

Customer service was great on this book.  But that's not what I want to talk about. This book. Oh. my. gosh. This book. I have had my eye on this book for awhile now, just never had the chance to pick it up until someone gave me a giftcard for Amazon. This was THE FIRST book I thought of. And boy, when I say buying this book was one of the best choices I've ever made, I am not kidding. This book was great! Crammed full of so many referances to books, tv shows and old games, this book have me on the edge of my seat. I couldn't put it down. Definitely worth it.

I'll just cut to the chase - this is a great book. It's an 80s geek's dream - Megaman, Rush, Family Ties, Zork, the list goes on and on. But beyond that, it is a clever and well written piece of fiction. I literally could not put the book down once I got into the last 100 pages of it. Trust me, you want to read this. In a world of too many vampires, zombies and bondage-loving businessmen this rises above the ordinary. It will make you think, and if you're a child of the 80s(like me) it will almost feel like recapturing a bit of your childhood in the process.

I couldn't put this book down once I started reading it. With the small, subtle hints at the various classic books, games, music and television shows that are all favorites from our childhood, it was hard not to feel the nostalgia. The characters are real and the conversations between them don't feel forced or faked. I'm about to read it a second time and am hoping to see a sequel someday to satisfy my desire to see more of the OASIS and what diabolical things the IOI will do next to get what they want. One of the best books I've read in a very long time.

This is by far one of the best books I've read in a really long time. I devoured it in 36 hours. I've never written an Amazon review before but I felt compelled that this book deserved one. I was only 4 when the 80's ended so a lot of the pop culture references didn't resonate with me like I'm sure they did for those who grew up in that time period. However, I'm a pop culture nerd so I did recognize a fair share of the reference. Even if you're not a total geek like me, if you like sci-fi/distopian fiction, this is the book for you. Read it immediately.

If you fondly remember the 1980's then you'll love this story. It's set in a dystopian 2045. The founder of a software company  designs an immersive virtual reality universe. After he dies the virtual reality will be set up declares who ever solves his riddle to open three gates and beat the challenges behind them will inherit his fortune and control of his company. It's five years before someone finds the key to the first gate. Much of the virtual reality universe, OASIS, in the book is based on 80's video games, TV shows, and movies. It's a fun read.
Great book. Well written...like you were seeing the story through his eyes.

My brain is still processing the depths and social implications of this work, but Cline has managed to brilliantly capture the pulse and heartbeat of nerds and geeks everywhere with one of the most intelligently laid plots with masterful command of the perfect allusions to the origins of our geek culture, sending some of us down memory lane and other younger readers into a deLorean to experience and appreciate the games, movies, shows, and books that helped give birth to the world they enjoy today. In Og's words, Mr. Cline, "Ya did good, kid!"

Fantastic book. More pop culture references than you can shake a ALF doll at. I couldn't put it down, which is why I was able to devour it in less than 24hrs. It will be re-read again, I can assure you. Received it, along with tons of other subscribers, in my most recent LootCrate. I've been wanting to read this since I first found out about it, and was overjoyed to see it arrive along with the usual assortment of awesome stuff. Superb read, keeps you on edge, and makes you laugh. Its a great book that will be enjoyed for generations to come.

I really, really enjoyed this book! Very original concept yet still familiar enough to grab onto.  I said several times while reading Ready Player One that it may very well be the most FUN I have ever had reading a novel, a shameless geeky delight.  Full of fun 80's pop culture references that call me back to childhood.  As a result of reading the book I have gone back and revisited many of the shows, movies, and games referenced in the book.  Really well done, ESPECIALLY as a first novel.  I look forward to seeing what he comes up with next.

I knew this book would be pretty good when I bought it.  I just didn't know how good.  I couldn't put it down.  Even with 4 kids at home, a full schedule, and books piling up on the bed stand and on the kindle, I found myself plowing through this one.  Skipping TV shows, pretending to be tired to go to bed early, etc.  I had to know what happened next.  The 80s references are great, and I plan to look up some of these old games that I missed and find them on xbox or the computer.  Absolutely loved the book and hope he writes more.

I really really enjoyed this book. I’m not a gamer and not nostalgic for the decade of the ‘80s, but I had fun with the memories of the TV shows, movies and songs that the author referenced throughout the book. I thought it was a terrific idea for a landscape for the story. Oh yes, there is an adventure, mystery, thrills, good guys, bad guys and even a sweet love story that develops over time. I was sad to reach the end of the story I had escaped to, but I’m sure there will be more imaginative stories coming from this author.

Get ready to submerse yourself in a world where virtual reality is the only place to find refuge from the harshness of the real world. When the creator of the virtual world of Oasis dies, a contest begins to determine who will inherit the enormous wealth left behind and have ownership of Oasis.  Gamers everywhere begin the quest to solve the riddle left by the software developer.  The biggest threat is the resolve of a greedy corporation to win the challenge by any means thereby ending free access to the epic world of Oasis.

Everyone should read this book, especially if you were a kid in the 80's!!!  Even if you were not, you should read this book because it is well-written, has a great sense of humor, is exciting and suspenseful, and it draws you into a world that is SO sad to leave!  The 80's pop-culture references is like nostalgia candy, and you will find your geeky self smiling and yelling "Awesome!" throughout the entire book.  It's very clever, and you know you want to dork out every once in a while!  It should make a fun movie for sure.

Written by a gamer for gamers, obviously. The story left me wanting to know what happens to its broken world after the conclusion, maybe the author will take us a little further in a follow up title. I read this in just over a day, mainly because the pacing was good and I couldn't put it down. Recommended read, 4* out of 5 stars. *if you are old enough to have played systems like the original Atari, and cabinet video games from their early days. This is not required, but you will certainly enjoy the pop culture references.

Since Neal Stephenson is no longer interested in writing decent sci-fi (I haven't read Reamde yet), this book fits the bill quite nicely.  An excellent homage to 80's team up movies (think Lost Boys and Goonies), except set in a dystopian future where everyone is jacked in 24-7-365 playing in an online MMORP that is better than real life.  The 80's video game/RPG/music/book/movie/TV show references per page is off the chart.  The perfect gift for the Gen-X nerd on your Christmas list...if they haven't bought it already...

It was totally an "E" ticket ride!!!! I am in my 50s, not really geeky and I LOVED it!!! It was very visual and creative with tons of references to the 80s. It was very interesting to me how the author made the future games and the past games fun, interesting and visual. I could really picture what was happening. I could go on and on, but just read the other reviews!!! I usually never go over .99¢ - $1.99 on a Kindle book, but I did with this one. It just sounded so interesting and truly it was worth the $3.99.

Read it in 3 days, which is a big deal if ya knew me. Fantastic book, would recommend to anyone who likes vr/classic games/scifi. Only 1 thing bad to say, the 80s references are bulky and seemed like it was forced in some parts. I grew up in early 80s so i got most references but a friend who is in his early 20s was lost by most which could limit the appeal to younger crowds. Still best book ive read in awhile cant wait for armada and the movie (so long as its done like the book and not slaughtered by screenwriters).

Part of the reason I may have enjoyed this book 5-stars worth is because I listened to it as read by Wil Wheaton. As a former player of World of Warcraft, I appreciated the take on the Massively Multiplayer Online Role Playing Game. I really liked the main character, I liked where the story went, I loved the world it was in.. it made me wish the Oasis was something I could jump online to now and play. I think this book is appropriate for any age. I wonder though if folks who aren't familiar with MMO would enjoy it.

Every once in awhile a book comes into my path that takes over my life for a week or so. It's all I think about and all I can relate to for however long it takes to get through which would be much quicker if I didn't have children, work or sleep to contend with. This is one of those Novels. I loved every word of it and loved logging into it like the characters logging into OASIS in the not too distant future. It made me appreciate a good dystopian sci-fi and this genre may just replace my Scientology obsession.

I wasn't sure what to expect with this book, but it was recommended to me by a friend. At first, it was a little hard to get into, but once I got into it, I was hooked. I really wanted to find out how the story panned out. I didn't necessarily get all of the movie and video game references, but that didn't hurt the story for me. If you are a big fan of 1980s popular culture, you'll probably enjoy the references. I liked the view of the future that this story provided, though I hope it doesn't come into being.
At times it feels like it could contain less nostalgia and more plot.

It's a great book that will keep you entertained the entire time you're reading it. There are a few slow moments here and there but it kept me reading and excited all throughout. A must-read for anyone interested in virtual reality type stuff and science fiction in general. Some websites will say its appropriate for 12+ but I would recommend at least 16+ because there are a lot of '80s references that millenials wouldn't understand as well as a few violent moments that may or may not be suitable to preteens.

I bought this book as part of a buy two get the third free promo - and this was the third, as I thought it might be amateurish or too referential  for people who were not gaming insiders. I was interested right on the first page and hooked by the first chapter.  There is a clear reason for the widespread focus on video games, TV, movies, and music GPS the eighties, and the author does a great job on explaining what the major references are. I really enjoyed the book and look forward to the author's next one.

I had the audio book and that generally makes most books "readable."  I got bored.  I didn't care about the main character.  I did enjoy the future world and the cyber world was neat but overall the book didn't reach me.  I've read other reviews that mention the anecdotes about 80s and 90s television and technology as a drawback but I kind of enjoyed that.  It was a pop culture history that offered some information.  I wouldn't pick it up again but some out there might enjoy it.  I'm sure a great many will.

I would recommend this book to anybody! The references to 80's pop culture really give this book an amazing and fun touch while the references to how the earth has degraded so drastically gives the book a sense of accuracy seeing how we treat the earth now. It's not surprising to think that if everyone became obsessed with an online video game that we would forget about the real world problems and everything would go down the toilet. Realistic, funny, clever, and just plain awesome. Three thumbs up 👍👍👍

I love this book!  It wraps technology, science fiction, fantasy, and the world of the 1980's all into a quick read!  I can't tell you how much this book hit a cord with me.  I relate so well to this book, how it is written, and the trivia in it.  If you like 80's trivia on movies, comics, books, music, toys, video games, and pop culture, this is a perfect book for you.  Think of the movie the Matrix with 80's trivia and a riveting story to drive it!  Just an awesome combination and well written to boot!

A quick reading, retro-themed cyber chase through the dystopian future. How could you go wrong? Well, this book mainly doesn't. It presents some interesting themes about poverty, internet "immersion", and corporate dominance. However, it also follows predictable plotlines, and seems slightly juvenile for people who would appreciate all the video nostalgia. As a 31 year old, my tastes are definitely more mature. I read it briskly, and enjoyed it, but I wouldn't really recommend it for my fellow 25+ crowd.

Very creative and insightful. However, I'm not a child of the 80's, I thought the 80's sucked, so the nostalgia was slightly wasted on me. Cline employs a rather limited vocabulary and does things like using 'they' multiple times in a paragraph for several pages in a row. Not exactly high prose. I have to assume that in ten years novels will read like long Twitter messages. That being said, I thoroughly enjoyed the book, staying up far too late because I had to finish it before I could sleep. Want more.

Ready player one is an amazing read. It got a bit weird when every single conversation had to have a ton of cursing, but other than that it was great.. I read it in about 2 days bvecause i just could not put it down. The plot was original and compelling.  It was the a perfect mix of of clever humor, well defined characters and a uniue story line. I dont want to give anything way so i wont say anythong more.. vut i defintitly reccomend this book. The ending is great so great so make sure to finish it.

Really enjoyable book the pulls on all the heart strings of an 80's kid that played more video games then sports. From pop reference to pop reference this hits home again and again. There is a phrase mentioned in the book and if you don't know the movie the last star fighter you won't get it. There is non stop little gems consistently throughout this book of coveted nerd dom.  A must read for anyone who is a fan of video games, D&D; and the 80's. "I never played D&D; but still loved this book."

I admit I've been feeling nostalgic for a while now, so this book couldn't have dropped in my hands at a more perfect time. I still dream of this future, the full immersion of an alternate reality you craft yourself. I found myself able to empathise with both Parzival and Halliday, seeing flashes of my own childhood from Halliday and echoes of my own thoughts the first time I played a MUD from Parzival. The nods I've seen to Neuromancer are well earned. A must read for anyone born in the early 70's.

When I first heard about this book, I thought that it was mostly a nod to big-time gamer's of the 80's.  While I did grow up in the 80's and played some video games, I didn't consider myself a gamer.  My expectations were wrong.  Anyone can find this story engaging and exciting as long as they can except the premise that people of the future spend a great deal of time in a virtual world.  Everything else is simply an adventure of good against evil and David vs Goliath.  I highly recommend this book!

This book is about videogames and a contest. I am not a gamer (I'm actually terrible at video games) but I really enjoyed this book. I could dip into my inner nerd and relate to the main character. The contest and puzzle aspect of the book made for a very entertaining story. I didn't get most of the 1980s references or any of the videogame references but that didn't really matter for the story. I would recommend to anyone but especially someone into videogames and who may have grown up in the 80s.

Please do not miss this. It's a delicious romp in a ruined future America.  Video games are central to the novel, which turns some people off.  I don't even play video games, but if you lived through the 80s AT ALL, ever had a nintendo or atari on top of your enormous TV cabinet on the floor, or if you just enjoy a richly developed dystopian world, it is worth your time.  That being said, it is not a teenage dystopian pop-novel at all.  Adults do not be afraid to have this in your book collection!
