This book took me hook, line and sinker!  I loved the vivid details that struck my memory circuit with a ping, pang, and pong!  Before I even finished this delightful novel, I knew I would be buying copies for friends and family.  And I did actually order one for my teenage nephew before getting to the final delicious climax. Why him specifically...well he could just as well have been Player One! An absolute must read for all geeks and non-geeks alike!  Yippee Yahoo Geek-a-zoids rock this world!!!

This should go down in history as one of the greatest geek-fests of all time. LOVED EVERY PAGE! I couldn't put it down,  took a day of work to keep reading. It's overflowing with references only the most dedicated gamers will get and it also has great taste in movies and TV shows. Dearest Author, I am not at all adverse to begging for a sequel because you know W.O.W. is going to have to hit that button. Readers,buy it before he gets too famous and you can only get a copy of this book at Comi-con.

Ready player one will not go down in history as great literature with Shakespeare, Melville, or Tolstoy. That being said, Ready Player One is a fun fun book. The Phantom Tollbooth for the 80s generation. An adventure that combines virtual reality with nostalgia. Part of the pleasure of this read is trying to "get the reference". If you woke up on Saturday morning to watch cartoons; if you remember when MTV actually played music and you collected quarters for the arcade, this book is for you.

I love this book!  Chock full of 80's references, it's the perfect book for a video game or D&D; nerd.  My 10 year old son read it, too, and couldn't put it down.  He read it straight through in about a day and a half, and I usually can't get him to read anything!  Be forewarned, though, it's not really for younger readers.  There is a lot of questionable language, and one rather uncomfortable to explain scene with an anatomical robot.  Overall, though.  it's a great book with a great plot.

Just like the characters in the book were obsessed with life inside the OASIS, I was obsessed with this book and couldn't put it down! I never wanted to leave this fantastic novel. I wasn't even alive during the 80s, which are highly referenced in the novel, but that didn't matter at all. Cline created a world, story, and characters that are hard not to fall in love with. One of my new favorite novels for sure. Stop reading this review and purchase the book already! You won't regret it.

this book was recommended to me by a close friend. I have not read a fiction book in decades, and thoroughly enjoyed this book. As a child of the 80's myself, computer and video game junkie, this was truly literary candy. Very well written, the author paints vivid landscapes with his words, and the background story, action, references to all this toys and games I grew up with, combined with various plots, puzzles and twists and turns, make for fantastic if quick read. Highly recommend.

In a nutshell: at its best, a gripping and highly original, nostalgia-packed thriller that makes you want to stand up and cheer for the good guys; at its worst, a ham-handed Snow Crash ripoff stuffed to the gills with self-congratulatory 80s trivia and trite polemics.  I can't bring myself to put it on the same pedestal as "the greats" of SF, but at the same time, I'm also on my fourth read this month.  For its flaws, it's still one hell of a trip and a mighty impressive first novel.

I won't waste time telling you how good the "book" is, as others have done that very well (and the book definitely deserves a 5* rating). I just need to give kudos to Wil Wheaton. Wil does his usual audiobook effort here, which is to say that he _completely_ "owns" this. If you've never taken in one of his works (e.g. his reading of a Scalzi novel), then even if you've "read" the book already, do yourself a favor at some point, and "re-read" it again, by listening to Wil's rendition.

Great dystopian sci-fi novel with way too many geek culture references from the 80's and on (in a good way). I was surprised at how up-to-date it was with those references, but I fear that they will severely date this book in a few years. Regardless, it a great read for any age group that will be able to appreciate call backs to movies like Back to the Future, Tron, War Games, Lord of the Rings - basically, all that the sci-fi/fantasy buffs already know like the back of their hands.

Don't let the fact that the main characters are a bunch of gamers throw you.  The story is much more than a homage to geekdom.  The book is fully accessible to non-gamers and is actually a thrilling treasure hunt - - one that takes place in an on-line universe constructed out of the cultural icons that made up the 1980s, even though the story takes place in 2045. It is full of action, danger, life-and-death situations, love, and honor.  It's almost impossible to put the book down!

Loved this book! If you are looking for something complex with multiple layers and pretentious writing to it then this book probably won't be for you. It's a fun and well developed story with easy to love characters that make you cheer for them to the very end. As a child born in the 80's it was fun to reminisce about some of the references and silently shout "I remember that!" and although I didn't get all of them; who cares! It was an easy read that I couldn't put down.

Oh man... I blasted through this book, because I just could not stop. Being a child of the 80s - and not one of those phony, "I was born in 1989, so I'm an 80s-kid" child of the 80s - this book was constantly reminded me of how wonderful it was growing up in that era. The plot is INSANELY believable. The future stuff is just future-y enough and not blown out of proportion. The characters area really fun to get to know. Read it before it becomes the next big blockbuster.

My high school and college days were during the 80's so it was nostalgic to read this book with many references to pop culture of the 80's. I also use to play video games back then so it definitely brought back memories when the book mentions games like Dig Dug! I'm in the tech field so it was fun to go into this future world of 2044 and see what kind of world could exist where your online persona is who you are! I enjoyed the story, a trip to the past and the future.

This book was suggested to me by my nerdy English teacher who shares a name with a lovely old lady in this story. The plot, characters, and story elements are all addicting and I found that it was extremely hard not to read this book. I have had it for two days and the only reason I didn't finish it the day I bought it was because it was 3:00 in the morning and because it was 3 days before Christmas so things were a bit hectic as you can imagine... Either way READ THIS BOOK!!!

What a great book! It kept me turning the pages and smiling at the 80's references. Good plot, however, I found myself somewhat bored in the middle of the book The story started to slow down and the author didn't seem where to go next. The ending was quick and not quite what I expected. Nice character development and a great idea. I would definitely recommend this book to friends and others. I am curious to see what else the author writes in the future.

Ernest Cline has written one of my favorite books ever, Ready Player One. Not because it is the greatest piece of fiction but because I am a child of the 1980s. This book made so many of the great pop-culture moments from my childhood come to life in entertaining as well as nostalgic ways. If you're a fan of Star Wars, Back to the Future, Pac-man, The Atari 2600, Monty Python, or thousand other pop-culture references from the 80's themI think you will dig this book.  Because it is so generation specific I'm not sure it is a book that will stand the test of time, before its intended audience I think it has achieved its goal.

I have been a voracious reader all my life. I have been buying and reading Amazon(Kindle) books for a couple of years now. I have to say that this book is the only one I have had major problems putting down. Staying up WAY too damn late reading. I am not done with the book yet, but hope beyond measure that there is more to this story when I reach the end. I can not express my enjoyment of this book, it is one of the only books that I will buy just to gift to a friend to read!

My daughter grew up in the 80's. This book was a wonderful tour down memory lane, her first video game, us as a family learning how to use computers, just a blast. The book is a tense little thriller and even though at times a bit predictable but, is it so well written, I didn't care. Hard not to give away spoilers, so just will say, I would recommend this book to anyone, from teen to adult. Especially if you or your kids grew up in the 80's. Currently, I'm reading it again.

I received this book as a gift. I had looked at it a few times and passed on buying it, Mostly due to the fact was thinking it would be similar to the mocking jay and descent style books. I figured I would spend the whole time wondering where are all the parents? I am delighted to say this is not the case. I ended up reading it all the way through in less than 24 hrs and am lacking sleep I could not put it down. This was a fantastic read! I highly recommend reading this one.

This was so enjoyable, truly an entertaining book that was off the hook clever and rad! Growing up in the eighties, I was able to completely connect and appreciate all the 80's pop culture references as if my childhood memories were unfolding in front of me. That, compared with the other science-fiction, fantasy story-line and race to save the universe made it engaging and interesting the whole way through. This is one of my favorite books ever and sure to be a cult-classic!

A fun, engaging read. I loved the atmosphere of the world. The rules were well-established, and the characters were likeable. The author did a good job building up the relationship between main character Wade and competitor/love interest Art3mis. I also enjoyed how the book questioned whether one could fall in love with someone they haven't met in person. It's not an original concept, but in Cline's online world, it worked very well. I really enjoyed this imaginative read.

This story is of a gamer in his dream world, life is a game school work everywhere is based on a game, but it also say the consequences of a gamer's world it become apocalyptic where everything is no longer in reality this book brought me back my wishes of life as a game were some what fantasized life wouldn't be pretty well this is all the spoilers I will give you read to find out the true story my last thing to say is that life shouldn't reside in a game but is reality

If you were born in the late 60s early 70s, remember D&D;, are any kind of geek who loves DragonCon / ComicCon how dare you not have this book? By far the best book Ive listened to all year. Im only a couple hours in and I laughed out loud I cant tell you how many times. Talk about having my childhood flash before my eyes. FREAKING FANTASTIC. I hear Warner Bros has already bought the movie rights.... so read it fast because its absolutely worth whatever you pay for it!!!!

Loved this thing, it kicks so much ass, on so many levels. I'm not going to try and describe what it's about, read the description. Does that sound even remotely interesting to you? Even if it only sounds remotely possible that you will like this thing. I believe you should buy it, love it, read it twice. If this book were a person I would marry it, even if that required one of us to alter our genders or sexual orientations to accomplish that feat. Yes, it's that good.

This book really took me by surprise. I really wasn't expecting that much, but a friend of mine suggested it, and the reviews were really good. So, I figured I would check it out. Wow! What a great book! It is intelligently written, with excellent plot twists, and overall it is just a really good story. I don't think I could recommend a book any more then this one. If you like science fiction or video games in any way, you owe it to yourself to read this. Aw3some Book!

Really enjoyed it.  It's a fantasy world all contained in a book for those who love video games (teen or adult), as well as the 1980s.  I'm not, myself, someone who plays many games, but I found the book fast paced, well written, well paced and I liked it a lot.  I HIGHLY recommend it as a high quality book for teen boys, but I also think it's complex and developed enough to completely entertain adult readers.  A great book for a parent to read along with their child.

Received this book in a Loot Crate and absolutely LOVED it!!!  I could feel the tension right there along with Parzival in his quest for the key's.  Every-time another score went higher I was worried along side Parzival.  I recommend this book to anyone!!! (especially those nostalgic of the 80's).  Being able to understand all the pop culture references definitely enhanced the read quite a bit.  Took me back to my childhood.  Shame there was no ninja turtle reference.

Just finished the book a few minutes ago and I simply had to leave a review. Have you ever read a book and 20 pages in you're already in love with it? Me neither. Have you read through half a book and felt sadden by the fact that it'll end? Me neither. I've always thought nothing could be better than Ender's Game, but this book....wow, I'm speechless. Simply stated, the best book I've ever read...EVER. If you consider yourself a geek, this book should be your bible.

This book really hit home for me. As a child of the eighties I was able to read along and remember everything that was talked about in the book. I just loved it, it was a great story and a large dose of nostalgia. If you were born in the late seventies or eighties and were into pop culture this is a book for you. Exactly what you would expect from this kind of story too, not heady at all just straight forward fun. Read the book then get out the old Atari and enjoy.

If you're a fan of video games, pop culture, anything from the 80s, and things that may be considered "geeky" or "nerdy" you HAVE to get this book. I was hooked from the first page and I couldn't stop reading until I had finished it. It's not "Catcher in the Rye" and it's third act seems a little rushed, but it's still darn good. You owe it to yourself if you grew up in the late 70s, 80s, 90s, play video games, love sci-fi, to buy this book.

Ready Player One is probably one of the best books I have ever read! The story kept me engaged the entire time without any slow parts that would normally make me want to skip ahead. Wil Wheaton's narration was so full of emotion I felt like the maiwn character, Wade was telling the story himself! If you buy the kindle version, I highly recommend the audio upgrade for the immersive reading. It is worth every penny! I cannot wait to read more of Ernest Cline's work!

Not because this is the best book I read all year ("Just Kids" gets that), but because it was a strong contender and just so damn much fun to read. Engaging, and witty, 'Ready Player One' melds so much of what I love about sci-fi with just enough self-awareness to be endearing too. Does it feel a bit forced in places? Sure, all that fan-boy zeal has to. Did it detract from the story, or how much I liked reading it? Not a bit - it actually makes it more believable.

Ready Player One is as good, and back-and-forward thinking as Neuromancer by WIlliam Gibson is, except you don't have to read this one twice to fall head over heels for it. Other reviews will tell you the plot but I'll tell you this: if you ever put a quarter in a video game in the 80s, you are gonna love this book. I was distraught the night I knew I was gonna finish it, and WOW! what a finish. Now anxiously waiting for MRS. READY PLAYER ONE. Bring it on, Ernest!

When I found myself standing in an open field west of a white house, with a boarded front door. I was in heaven. Each reference to the past was an incredible journey into my own childhood. This book has so many setting that are so vast and yet familiar. If you were any thing like me you will enjoy the journey as i did. Even the musical references are unforgettable. I wanted to been in the story so bad. Yes even as Mathew Broderick playing Galiga in a pizza joint.

I am not a gamer or an 80s trivia fanatic, so at first glance you would think that I wouldn't pick this book up. But alas I did and I'll continue to pick it up and reread. It's probably the most fun I've had reading a book in a long time. 100% pure enjoyment - it was funny, fast moving, endearing, and I was completely engrossed. Loved the writing style and how easy I was able to follow along. I felt like I was in the book. Completely refreshing, highly recommend.

Loved the story, loved the pace, adored the unique concept......just an amusingly fast paced read. If you are searching for a youthful unusual book that will keep you rooting for the "good guys" right through the last page---look no further! This is it! I actually read one page at a time when I got to the last 10 pages..........I hesitated in finishing it because I feared I'd not find another book to equal the excitement of this one. Very refreshing read.

The sad thing about this book is that it ends. I wanted it to last forever. But as all good things must come to an end, so to does this book. Thankfully, this book's conclusion is every bit as satisfying as all the pages that came before it. It is an expertly crafted homage to all sorts of 1980's entertainment culture, and it is a must read for anyone who knows and enjoys the feeling of disappearing into a book, movie, game, or even losing themselves in a song.

This is very much a book for a specific demographic - I imagine it would be almost incomprehensible to anyone who isn't a Gen-X (maybe Gen Y) nerd. The premise that world culture is stuck in an 80's time loop is both amusing and a little horrifying. I sometimes wondered if in catering to the desire of geeks to live in some sort of 80's nirvana he was also quietly riffing on the idea that hell is a place where nothing changes. This book reads well a second time.

I will not speak long about this novel.  However there are something that need to be said.  This book is does a realy good job of drawing the audience into the post modern world that has become of humanity.  It also does and excellent job describing the OASIS and what is for many of the people who use it for their average every day lives.  For those of you who like to read I recommend this book but for those of you who like older video games it is a must read.

I believe this is a solid, entertaining, not wanting to end........4.5 stars book. 5 is reserved for the alltime greats, but i truly feel the few 1 star ratings given are just wrong so i gave away half a star to compensate. If you like video games, the 80's, witty dialogue, friendship and even a little romance damn you are going to like this book. If you have the opportunity to listen to audible version of this book you are in for a treat. Well done Mr Cline.

This book is aimed squarely at those who grew up in the 80s --- hooray for us!  I enjoyed the book greatly on its own merits and because of my demographic.  I cannot see anyone over 45 getting the book (it would be like reading Gunther Grass with no knowledge of European history, and for those under 30 they may enjoy and understand the technology angle well enough but few of the references (if Skolnick doesn't have a nerdy resonance with you, don't bother).

I had no idea whether or not I should even review this book yet. Or ever. I enjoyed reading it. And that's what I find odd. Why? Why did I enjoy a book about video games? What's so entrancing? It's not crazy exciting. It's original I guess. But yet I couldn't stop. I was born in 84, and only got some of the 80s references, but still... I'm still confused obviously. Not sure if I love it or hate it. Just read it. and judge for yourself. I'm giving it 4 stars.

I read this in three days, as soon as I'd finish work, till I fell asleep. If you're a nerd or a closet nerd like me, this book is like the best dream you've ever had, or the most imaginative thing you've ever imagined while speculating on the existence of the galaxy of Star Wars or if we really live inside the Matrix. This book is everything. Read it now. And then encourage them to make it into like at least 3 movies, so everything in the book can be in it.

My husband bought this book and I picked it up when he was finished. I didn't expect to like it, since I don't read scifi at all. I loved this book! The story is well written and the characters are so alive. It's a dystopian future that is not so unreal that you can't see it happening. Cline's commentary on the online life gives this story a wonderful undertone that I enjoyed immensely. Even if you don't read scifi, try this one! It'll change your mind.

I shouldn't like this book but I do. Deus Ex Machina is rampant, the main character contradicts himself in different parts of the book and the outcome is predicatable from very early on. Yet, I found myself racing back to read the book. Maybe it was the pop culture references or the puzzle nature of the book but I found it delightful. I hope Cline's writing improves because if he can keep finding that X factor for me, I'll want to read his future works.

This is mostly a fun future adventure. Remember when you first started the HP series and it was wondrous and new. That is the feeling I got with this book. I will say- from almost the first page of the book the author tells you this is a gigantic 80's pop/nerd/hacker/rock/ culture reference. So with that in mind, the story develops and is resolved in an 80's movie fashion. In regards to this, the book is 100% self fulfilling. And all the better for it!

This book was honestly one of the best that I've ever read. With an original storyline and creative, interesting characters, a captivating plot, drama and action, Ready Player One had me hooked from page one, and kept pace throughout. love friendship, betrayal, drama, fighting, action, robot-like gaming suits and an incredibly realistic world that I could understand why the characters didn't want to leave the Oasis; I wouldn't mind being there myself!

Anyone who loves videogames, is a self-proclaimed geek, or loves the 80's should read this book! Set in the near future where the world is doomed, people log on a virtual reality game as their escape. When the creator of this virtual world dies he announces that there is a hidden treasure inside the game, and whoever finds it will inherit his fortune. So the whole world goes on this mission. Overall really great book, one of my favorite recent reads.

You didn't have to grow up in the 1980's to appreciate and for that matter love this book. I'm only 18 and I loved this book! I haven't read many book in my life, but this absolutely takes that cake for being my favorite. If you read this book, you'll get lost in the vivid world inside the OASIS that Cline describes. He makes up a future society that is in every way a realistic and possible representation of human society. The book is perfect. haha

Merry trip through 80s pop techno culture. Was a bit too much like informational writing in early chapters describing ins and outs of all things 80s and not enough character development nor events a-happening. But rocking ruckus of videogame play-by-play later on that was very entertaining. Many missed opportunities to comment on or analyze consequences, both positive and negative, of obsession with digital world, leading to a skin deep adventure.

This book appeals to a certain kind of nerdy 80s loving audience that I am a part of. It's fault lies with this because some people might have to spend a lot of time looking up things just to get a good picture in their head of what is going on. It also spends a little to much time explaining environments and new tech unique to the game. Besides these two things it was a fun read that I can see myself reading to my kids one day with some editing.

The challenges of living in cyber space juxtaposed to real life make this such a great story of the frightening world in our near future.  I truly enjoyed the connection with the '80s.  Now I have my kid reading it.  As a child of the 2000's, he occasionally asks me about some of the references the author used but he's digging it!  My only worry is that he's excited about life in the Oasis instead of being scared to death about it ... like me.

Ready Player One is speculative fiction set in the near future and examines the consequences go our cultures growing escapist mentality. Cline does an excellent job keeping the pace of the novel moving and references so much "geek culture" that the novel almost turns in to a game of "guess that reference". If you love pop culture from the late 70s to early 90s or enjoy a quick read about video games, this is a book for you.

Ready Player One is a book about video games, obsession, virtual reality, greed, pop culture, society, sociopaths, love and much more. Should you read this book, you will be led through a virtual world called the Oasis on a hunt for an insanely well hidden Easter egg.  You will share the many triumphs and setbacks of the main character and will learn a lot about the history of gaming along the way.  It is rare to find a book this good. 5/5

Not at all what I had expected.  Although a bit formulaic, it is a wonderful romp through a dystopian near future with strong ties to the 80's childhood many of us experienced.  The writing may qualify this as either light reading or young adult lit, but it is well worth the read for anyone who has ever used a floppy disk, played in an arcade, or rolled 20 sided dice.  I devoured this book in three sittings and would gladly have seconds!

Born in 1976, I guess I am a true "geek."  I can not remember the last time I had so much fun reading a book and each page felt like a trip back to any given day of my childhood.  What other piece of literature will ask you to think about interpersonal skills, pacman, Atari, indentured servitude, D & D, montey python and more all in the same work.  Do not deprive yourself of this great book.  I just wish the author had a follow-up ready.

Every once in a great while, one finds a book that resonates so deeply that the reader assumes the author intended it just for him or her. This is that book. But it wasn't written only for me. It was written for all of us who grew up in the '80s, playing video games and D&D;, watching science fiction and fantasy movies, and hoping that one day we would find someone to love who loved these things too. I can't wait to read this book again.

This book is for any nerd, geek, comics, video game, Movie or music fan! Any one of us geeks born in the late 60's growing up in the 70's and 80's. Well this book is a historic volume of geek pop culture with an awesome cast of characters and a wicked cool plotline. I went through this book in 23 hours easy, then re-reading again right now taking it slower but still having that awesome fresh, nostalgic feeling of that imagination.... :)

This book was recommended to my by a fellow gamer friend. A first I thought it was going to be a typical underdog story. The backgrounds resonates with the current world issues. The book is well told and takes a familiar idea an  makes it interesting. The ending is satisfying but their are parts that have you still feeling that the antagonists got off easy. I highly suggest this book to any one who loves the spirit of mmo's and gaming.

The book was a page turner in the fact that I was curious about what happened next and interested in the technology they described.  However the plot was fairly predictable.  At certain times in the book new ideas were brought up that either hurt or helped a character and it seemed as if they were just made up to justify the next situation for the character (vs a smooth transition). A good light read and fun references to video games.

Simply put, it is a geek-tastic book where every person on this planet that minmially categorizes themselves to the words geek, dork, nerd, and so on should pick up this book and definitely should give it a go. Even if you're just looking for a good read of much adventures, phenomenal creativity, relatable and honest characters, and just another whole new universe to delve into, I implore you to give it a try. You will not regret it.

Sci-fi novel about video games – definitely not something I would have chosen on my own. But when my bookclub chose it, I dove in & was pleasantly surprised. I didn't get all of the references, but the author did a great job of explaining where necessary, while not overdoing it. I thought it was a tiny bit cheesy at times, and a little predictable, but I found myself thinking about it in the car, and looking forward to reading more.

Understand, I'm a long-time geek at heart.  That being said, in terms of pure fun, this book is the best time I've had in YEARS!!  If you have any affinity for '80's pop culture, sci-fi, fantasy, anime, role-playing and of course, video games and game history, you will eat this novel up.  I felt like someone was totally speaking my language; it's not just a few scattered references to the culture...it's a full-on homage.  Loved it!

After finishing this book,I still can't believe how much of the best parts of my childhood (and even adult life) are paid loving homage in a book set in a dystopian future that no one would really hope for. The further I read, the harder I found the book to put down. I genuinely cared about the characters, and while I was occasionally able to predict what was coming in the short term it still held its share of surprises. Loved it.

I don't play video games. I never played D&D; games, did not read fantasy or sci-fi books as a kid or any of the otherwise awesome s*** I could have been doing. I feel like I've made up for a childhood of not doing all of that by reading this book. What a great ride, plainly laid out in the best adventure-style way. I'm going to force this book on all of my friends who are gamers and fantasy geeks but haven't read a book in years.

A quick glance at the cover-flap copy gives you a strong idea of what you'll get in this book. And the book proceeds to deliver on the promise of the ad copy--unusual in itself. But the book captures adolescent life and pseudo-life pinpointing the anxieties of coming-of-age, but not needlessly harping one them. Exceedingly well done and a lot of fun for those looking for a quick, light read to fill out the remnants of the summer.

A must read for children of the 80's, or fans of 80's pop culture. This is an excellent read, with some decently fleshed out characters (who only somewhat suffer from the whole "best at everything" trope, which ends up being slightly subverted), an evil comcast-analog, and an interesting "mad mad mad mad world" esque puzzle hunt. I really enjoyed this one, and found myself smiling at the ending. Excellent read.

I don't know if it was the fact that nostalgia for my childhood caused this book to stay with me so much, after I finished it, or the fact that the characters were so likeable and the story was so interesting (it's probably all of the above), but this book was so enjoyable, I recommended it to everyone.  I even purchased some copies and sent them to my friends.  If you're a child of the 80s, you'll particularly love this book.

There is no way I could possibly write a review that would provide adequate praise to this book. All I can and will say is that ages 1-1000 and of all areas of the world that have shared an affinity for the classics of the 1980's must share this story with themselves as well their children's children and on. Bravo to its author for making me feel like a kid and allowing me to relive all the lives I've had throughout the ages!

Geek out Alert!!!  A total must read for all gamers, music lovers, 80's pop culture fanatics and anime/comicon geeks!  What a love letter to all things 80's and I was in school during the whole Reagan/Rubix Cube era. I laughed at loud to the funny movie references and the name of the dance software. I have read the book and have am now I my second listen to the audio book. Read excellently by Wil Wheaton! Listen and have fun!
It's a great history about the old 80's years. I love it!

Think of Charlie and the Chocolate Factory written for modern grown-ups, or Ender's Game without the self-important stuffiness. It's a pretty well-written story with a good set of characters anchored by a very good protagonist. It's good enough that the local library (Huntsville, AL - not a small town) chose it for a recent month's book club read. I see it being made into a movie. Read it before then so you can say you did.

For anyone that grew up in the eighties, Ready Player One is a trip down memory lane, yet is a looking glass into our future. This book is full of 80's pop culture references that had made me lough out loud. Also, The philosophical implications will also leave you thinking about how technology can overshadow our social economic condition and what happens when the lines are blurred between real and digital human interaction.

It's about time someone from my generation, someone who grew up hopelessly addicted to all the same digital vices as me, sat down and put it all to paper. His book was as much a trip through all my favorite memories as it was a look into a future that, while bleak, contained technology that every geek has imagined - likely to the finest detail. I feel a sort of vindication having read this book; like the geeks finally won.

I cannot recommend this book enough.  Great plot, great characters.  Being a year older than James Halliday in the book, all of his obsessions and followings were mine.  I identified with both the main character Wade and Halliday.  So many references from my childhood and teen years wrapped up with a engaging story.  Once I got into the book.  I could not put it down.  I only wished there was some slight hint of Play-NET.
I thought the book was very slow to start, but picked up once the game was afoot.  If I was more of a gamer I'm sure I would have enjoyed it more.
I loved every second I spent reading this book. I wish I had written RPO. Get it! You won't regret it. ENJOY!

I'm a nerd, so I can relate to the characters.  I spent the 80's in MS and hated it.  If I'd met these people, I would have had a blast.  I read the book until midnight every night until I finished it
Don't have a lot of words for you, I just wanted to give my 5 stars and get out.  I loved this book and I recommend it to anyone reading my review!

This was great fun.  As a 40-something geek, this was a walk through my childhood.  Did you play Dungeons and Dragons? This book is for you.  Did you play video games on your Atari or Commodore 64? This book is for you.  Did you love cheesy 80s movies and/or music? This book is for you.  I picked it up to read over vacation and sped right through it (in a good way).  It was a fun read, good story, great nostalgia factor.

Fun book. It was hard to put it down. Fast paced and imaginative. A classic hero quest novel set in a dystopian future where the world is suffering from a decade long recession due to oil prices peaking and global climate change wreaking havoc on the planet. About a boy who hunts for Easter Eggs in a vast "Second Life" -esque virtual world to inherit the designers vast billions. I loved all the 80's references.

I think this is one of those books like "Daemon" and "Kill Decision" which are essential reading to get an idea of the futures that can/may unfold as technology progresses and we poor humans keep up with adaptation over evolution. However, it's not an especially well written book (characters, dialog etc). That said, it was very readable and I think my time spent reading it was enjoyable and productive.

This book is a great nostalgia trip for nerds who grew up in the 1980's. It is also a fast and fun adventure story with a little commentary about social isolation and the undelivered promise of virtual reality thrown in on the side. It might be a tough read for someone unfamiliar with the cultural reference points sprinkled throughout the book but if you've ever stepped on a four-sided die, then this book is for you.

Ready Player One is a well written book.  There is a fair amount of accurate pop culture references, technology history, and imaginative future gaming references.  I really enjoyed it and wished I'd read it years ago.  Great book for anyone who grew up in the early days of video games, or any one who is excited to see emerging technology used in virtual reality, and artificial intelligence made into gaming platforms.

This book was awesome! Normally I would never read this type of book (sci-fi) but after reading a review in a magazine I decided to order it.  I bought three copies total.  My kids, sister, brother-inlaw, and couple friends all agree.  If you remember the eighties and the video games from the 80's-90's you will find this book alot of fun to read.  I also rented the audio version to listen to and found it even better.

I thoroughly loved this book, read the audio version, so well done by Will Wheaton.  I had a hard time doing anything else while reading it, it was very much nerdgasmic.  I kept describing it to other people as I was reading it because I was having so much fun!  The universe the author created.was credible and fascinating.  I could have hung in there much longer for more adventures :)  Excellent, highly recommended.

A great book, one that definitely shows in a dark way the dangers of video games, and how it's easy to become absorbed so much so that basically life goes on the wayside. The characters were deep, while the main character made it easy to follow is sadness, his shame, and success and victories. It was a great book that I would highly recommend to anyone who plays video games, or anyone who likes books about dystopia.

It's likely to be mentioned in this tour-de-Force sci-fi sampler of geek culture. Along with the music, television shows, and films of those days. Prep for reading by rewatching Wargames, Bladerunner, Ladyhawke, Monty Python and the Holy Grail, play a few rounds of Pac-man, Adventure, Joust, and Tempest, then listen to the Spotify Ready Player One playlist as you read for the total 80s immersion experience. Game on!

As a child of the 80s this brought back a lot of memories. But it also had an interesting plot, likable characters, heart, and a good pace. The only reason I didn't finish it in one sitting was because it was 2am so I thought I should save a bit for the morning. With all the modern popularity of anti-heroes, sometimes it's nice to be able to have unequivocally good guys to root for. Plus the ending is very sweet!

By far one of the most amazing experiences I have ever read.Grounded in a future that is not to distant and this book is mind blowing. The images Cline develops are breath taking and creative. The topics he addresses are deep and thought provoking. I might never look at games, movies, books or 80s the same way. There are so many references that I have a whole new back log of things to indulge in. Love this book.

First off I'd like to give serious props to the author. This is by far one of the best books I've ever read in my entire existence on planet earth. It kinda saddens me because, although it may happen in the future, this technology isn't available yet. But other than that this was an amazing book that I totally geeked out to and will recommend it to everyone I know or will come to know for the rest of my life. 😀

I have 2 admissions,  I am a product of the 80's...and yes, I am a nerd.  Ignoring these 2 things, this is a really enjoyable read.  Adding in my first 2 admissions, it was OUTSTANDING.  Did not want it to end.  I do agree with those who say that it gets better as it goes, and at times it does feel a bit forced...but I just don't care.  The enjoyment level of this book is 5+ stars and it is a stellar first book.

I do not often write reviews, but I felt that this deserved some credit. This book is great. It is a fun scifi romp with crazy 80s pop culture references galore. I grew up in the 80s and I was a geek so I got almost all of the references whether explained or not. I think this added greatly to how much I enjoyed this novel. I highly recommend this book especially for those who meet the criteria of uber 80's geek.

Loved the characters and the suspense, loves the 1980's (and 70's) trivia.  Was a bit disappointed with how fast our main character adjusted to being rich and famous; hard to reconcile with the initial character we meet and no way to really account for the change.  Despite this, a fun and engrossing read I would recommend to anyone who enjoys Scalzi or similar.  Can't wait to read what Cline comes up with next!

A book for the geeks! And Cline is the the epitome and leader of all the nerds and geeks out there! This book is very informational and scientific all throughout. It makes me nostalgic on how I loved those 80's games that were famous before. Incredibly entertaining and awesome. Every sentence and paragraph makes you want to read more even for those non-gamers and just love reading a nice book. Truly a treasure!

I put this in the category of The Wizard of Oz, as a great story. I don't want to give it away, but after reading it, you will agree that it hopefully will become a movie. The basic premise is, a kid in the future, living a very simple life, has an opportunity to join a contest online, that could change his life, but I get the impression there is no electricity in his poor neighborhood. Somehow he gets online.

It's been a long time since I have read a book in less than a week (I'm a slow reader).  But I loved the plot and found it very hard to put down.  The story was not only a good read, but also thought provoking as one looks to the future of fully immersive  gaming.  I loved all the 80's references (like a trip down memory lane of the best of the 80's.)  Overall a great read and one I will remember for a while.

This book had me from the start. My husband suggested this book a long time ago, but I held off til I was ready to read it.  I am an 80's kid but did not play video games that much,therefore I didn't get a lot of the references in the book. However I did really enjoy the movie, tv and music references. So glad I finally read this great story. Hopefully they will make a movie. I just hope they do it right. :)

If you grew up any where near the 80's, this book is a treasure trove of childhood happiness wrapped in fast paced and slice story. The characters can be thought of as either thin, or just thick enough without slowing anything down. Cline is a master of pacing, allowing the story to progress without self-indulgence. As soon as he gives you a breather, he sucks you right back in. I couldn't put the book down.

It's not just the pop culture references that makes this book so fun, though it's partly that.  Mainly it's the books heart that I enjoyed so much.  The setting is grim and dystopian but the story is one of hope and heart and even honor, but most of all, Fun!  Those traits are sorely lacking in much of scifi/fantasy literature, making this book a real breath of fresh air.  Ernest Cline has Won the Game.  😇

I couldn't put this damn thing down. It is such a well written love letter to all these classic titles from days past. It grinds deep into the pitfalls of solitude and provides a deep, complex, but fun treasure hunt story that you could say rips off the genre, but it is really just paying wonder homage. I throw this down as a must read if you are strong with the nerd. You may find it annoying otherwise. A+

Talk about a great read! This book is a love letter to an entire decade! The pop references alone make this book nearly impossible to film so DON'T WAIT FOR THE MOVIE!  Honestly, as a product of the same era, I felt like the book was written just for ME at times! It is a constant page turner that keeps your interest peaked throughout. I can NOT recommend this book more highly! It is now a favorite of mine.

This book was awesome. Much of the 80's references went over my head (I want to defend myself and say many of them were pretty ----), but I still immensely enjoyed it. You want to root for the main character, and all of the supporting characters are written excellently. I would highly recommend this to anyone of the Sci-fi bent, and even those who are not that enjoy pop fiction references from the  80's.

As a child raised in the 70's and 80's, Cline's depiction of a futuristic society obsessed with the pop culture (and video games!) of that time period made for a story full of familiar things.  However, it was the twists, turns and puzzles within the story that have resulted in me reading twice already and buying 4 copies of it to give as gifts the Christmas.  A fabulous read - I hope he writes more.....

This story of Wade and his quest completely immersed me like no other book ever has. The references to the 1980s throughout the book provided an excellent trip down memory lane. Reading this book will make you want to rewatch movies and listen to music you haven't seen or heard in 30 years. I will definitely be reading this book again and hoping I live long enough to experience something like the OASIS.

Ready Player One by Ernest Cline is an excellent book.  It was recommended to me because of the 80's references but this book turned out to be so much more.  Set in the future, where everyone is immersed in trying to solve a huge video game created by a programmer obsessed with the 80's, this book takes you through the full range of emotions.  Mystery, intrigue, angst, and true love.  A true eye opener.

Don't know if this is someone who's dumbing down his technical knowledge or someone who's clearly not a technical person attempting to appeal to the nerd crowd. Fairly predictable and the writing was a bit elementary. It's got some good points about technology and dependence. The pace is slow but it IS a page turner. I bought it because of looking at what Loot Crate was about. Good read for the toilet.

If you are a child of the 80s you will love it. The story and prose are littered with references to geek culture of the period. The only problem is I thought the ending had a cheesy "message" tagged onto it. Also, some of the questions about what is going on with the society surrounding the virtual world are touched on but never answered. The prose is very basic but it's still a fun, fast read.

I can say that this is by far one of the coolest books I've ever read. It is a quick and easy read and I constantly found myself thinking about getting back to reading it when I was out and about during the day. I am a big movie fan as well as a tv series binge watcher. However, once I started the book, all my other hobbies fell to the background due to the intensity and total awesomeness of this book.

I was really excited to read Ready Player One and it didn't disappoint. I totally geeked out on this book. The 80's references are awesome, the universe Cline builds is one you want to escape into, and the plot is actually really compelling. Once I started this book I couldn't put it down. I'm not exaggerating when I say this book is now one of my three all time favorites. It's just a totally fun read.

I had borrowed this book from the library, but I enjoyed it so much I had to buy a copy.  My husband, who doesn't read as much as I do, chewed through this book very quickly and really liked it too.  Very suspenseful, imaginative, and funny.  As a child of the 80's, it was a special treat for me to come across the bits of 80's-related trivia sprinkled throughout.  Best book I've read in quite a while.

This novel is captivating, especially to those of geeky inclinations. One could enjoy this novel without them but they just make the book more fun. It not the best written thing but Cline knows how to tell a story. You'll find yourself flipping page after page and delving into chapter after chapter. Perhaps it ends a little predictably but that doesn't have to be a bad thing. Overall just a fun novel.

This is the first book I was compelled to finish in a sitting.  I can't remember the last time (other than children's books) that's happened.  Is it a world changer?  Nah.  Did it change my views on anything I hold near or dear?  Nah. Is it deep?  Hardly. It was just fun.  It has the right mix of nostalgia, pacing and character driven angsty-ness with enough nerd-hero bravado polish to get you there.

Really enjoyed this book, which was sent to me in my monthly Loot Crate subscription box. If you're a videogamer, especially a classic gaming buff, you will find much to love about this. The characters were well drawn and quite fascinating, and the author's vision of the future was intriguing. Depressing, but still very interesting. Will definitely look for other books from this author in the future!

A coworker recommended I read this, and I'm glad she did. Cline did an excellent job of incorporating 80's pop culture into a modern setting. I also felt elements of .hack in his story. There were a few instances of predictability, but I didn't mind them, because the character interactions held my attention. Also, Sorrento seemed a little too flat. Overall, it was a great book. I highly recommend it.

If you're super into 80s pop culture, this book is a fun walk down memory lane.  If you're here for the story, I've got some bad news.  The plot is unremarkable, the main character is a shameless Mary Sue, and the villain is so cartoonishly evil he may as well have been played by a cardboard cutout of Ricardo Montalbán.  As a concept, I liked it a lot; but I found the execution a little simplistic.

It had me at "Dogs and cats, living together.... MASS HYSTERIA!". So much stuff is crammed into this book, obscure 80's pop culture references, MMO stuff, sci-fi and fantasy book references, and finally.... there's a Wheadonverse. Oh, and Cory Doctorow and Wil Wheaton are President and VP of the user council. If you play MMO's and enjoy a fun geeky book give Ready Player One a try. Loved it!

I don't often read sci fi but this had solid reviews and an interesting premise. I'm glad that I jumped in. The story was really interesting and well developed. I don't consider myself much of a video game devotee, but the plot held my interest throughout. I cared about the characters and found the book well written. It moved a pretty quick pace and I was anxious to see what came next in the story.

Aside from the gaming descriptions sometimes being detrimental to the narrative flow, I really loved this book.  An 80s kid, I remember so many of the games and places referenced from that time - Showbiz Pizza and Aladdin's Castle were my escapes growing up.  This is not just a book that appeals to 80s pop culture and games, but a brilliant story of a boy's adventures in both fantasy AND reality.

This was a really fun novel. The frequent 80's pop culture references made me smile over and over. It brought back memories of my video gamer days in the 80's. What a blast! I liked this book so much I looked just now to see if there are other books written by the same author. Sadly, it appears not. I will certainly check back in the future to see if Mr. Cline turns out another gem like this one.

This book is amazing. I couldn't stop reading for 3 days straight. Anyone who is a geek,nerd, or anyone who likes the culture should read this book. It will make you laugh at all the references and also teaches you stuff you might not even know yet about your favorite comic books,movies, or games. Take some,relax,read, and appreciate this tomb, for it is for those of the past,present,and future.

I wouldn't normally give a book five stars if I wasn't blown away by both the plot AND the writing quality. Although the author's writing style leaves much to be desired, I had to give it five stars due to the fact that I haven't had this much fun reading a book in a long time. I read it straight through and couldn't even put it down for restroom breaks. It was entertaining from start to finish.

I picked this up out of curiosity during a business trip last month, and read right through it in a few days.  Not only are the references easy triggers to a ton of memories, the pace and style of the book reminds you of the very games and adventures it describes.  Weeks later, I am still thinking back to how much fun this was and wishing there was more where it came from.  Well worth the read.

If you grew up playing actual video games in actual arcades (for me it was the Magic Dragon), then you will absolutely love every single aspect of this book. Even if you didn't grow up in that age, you will be immersed in and in love with the 80's by the time you are done. All of that aside, it is an immensely fun and fast paced science fiction read. Stop reading reviews, and go buy this book!

Since I can remember I never was a fan of reading books, and believe me I tried many times but books never really clicked with me. Util I was going on vacation and decided to give Ready player one a try to my surprise I read the whole thing in about 2 days. Now I anjoy reading. I would recommend this book is for people who like video games and movies like the Matrix, sci-fi culture in general.

I am not a geek.  I hate the TV show Stargate, as well as all Star Treks and Star wars related films.  Having said that, I loved this book more than I have loved a book in a long time. It reminded of me Ender's game meets The Hunger Games, with a 1980's twist.  Really, please read this, you will be so very happy you did.

If youre a video game/old movies&shows;/lover of adventures kinda person you will LOVE this book. it takes you for an exciting futuristic ride with some truly loveable characters. i fell in love with the author's brilliant idea of the future of videogames. its action packed with the perfect amount of romance. i guarantee you wont be disappointed if you pick up this book. fun ride for all ages.

Honestly, there really isn't anything negative I can say about this book - it was a blast, start to finish and I was very sad to have it end. It was a nice bit of nostalgia combined with futuristic excitement, intelligent storytelling, fun characters and a central (albeit underlying) message that the real world can be painful but it can also be wonderful -- all the makings of book perfection.

Just finished reading this book and I have to say it was amazing. I just have the best feeling in my heart right now. I haven't felt this complete in a long time. What a wonderful story this author created. Took me way back to my childhood when I first discovered video games and Saturday morning cartoons. I recommend this to anyone looking to let their inner child out for a while. Loved it!!!

Like Halliday himself I was born in 1972 and grew up with so many of the games, movies and songs described in this book. The story itself was excellent but it was really all those references that hooked me and made me unable to put it down for any length of time. So thank you Mr. Cline for the wonderful walk down memory lane. This is the most fun I've had reading a  new novel in a long time!

... Most of the 80s references were over my head. (before my time) Still loved it, the only downside I see to this book is I now want a gaming system just like that lol. Sure, there were some parts that made me roll my eyes, but this is the authors FIRST book. I read (part of) this on a six hour road trip, kinda wanted to keep going so I could finish it! First for me, cause I hate car rides.

I listened to the audio version of the book, read by Wil Wheaton, and it was absolutely the most enjoyable experience I've had with ANY book in a long time. Without reiterating any of the good things written by other reviewers here, I highly recommend the audio version (from Audible.com). The narration is excellent, and I have listened to a lot of books. Very fun and read at a perfect pace.

This book was excellent. A real page turner. As busy as I am, I still read it in 5 days, just because I really wanted to know what happens next. Teens may enjoy it. It's an easy read. But they likely won't catch all the references. Being in my 40's, I caught 90% of them, as if the author tailored the book specifically for that age group. Absolute shame there aren't more books from this guy.

I am somewhat of a geek, and a programmer making it hard to find well written books that are targeted right at me. This book nailed it. There are so many books aimed at me but written at people who don't understand technology or understand me. Often those lousy books are then turned into movies by people also who don't understand technology or me. So many thanks to the author for this book.

Normally, I don't write reviews because I like to move onto the next book as soon as possible. However, as a child of the 80's and a casual gamer, this has to be one of the most fun and enjoyable books I have read in a long time. The concept is original and it's well worth the read. Even with 3 children and a full time job, I finished in 4 days. Definitely warrants the page-turner  status.

I LOVED this book. I read it over the course of a weekend and was blown away. I am an avid MMO player, and I really feel like this book got it right. It takes everything an MMO could be and adds so much more. The pop-culture references, the quest, the evil corporation..the EVERYTHING...He just gets it right. I can see how this world can easily happen. I for one welcome our robot overlords.

One of the best books incorporating the vintage computer game era.  I couldn't put this book down, the storyline was original and creative.  The dialogues were captivating and I really enjoyed how the author manages to warn about the dangers of being sucked entirely into a virtual reality.  To keep it short, if you like Atari games and pop culture, read this book.  No ifs, ands, or buts.

Good read for any Generation Xer! It was like going down memory lane lol! The characters are all well crafted and entertaining. The virtual world of OASIS and reality were both just as creative, giving a nice compliment to pacing. If you like Ender's Game coupled with great references to the grass roots of gaming and  70's/80's pop culture then be sure to check this book out. Good stuff!

I am very picky about what I read. I pick this book, read the back and was intrigued (which doesn't happen often!). Started reading it thinking I would probably put it down and forget about it but was I wrong! I love this book. The character and dialogue felt real. It made me want to play the games in the book. Read from cover to cover! Love it and I can not wait for your next one Cline!

This book was so much fun.  Geeky, pop-culture, fan-boy fun...But SO much fun if this is your thing.  Cline's incredibly creative and engaging story doubles as a love letter to the 80's.  This book defies easy categorization, as it slides from dystopian to sci-fi/fantasy (via virtual reality), hitting on other genres along the way.  It shouldn't work...but somehow it really, really does.

A blast from the past and future. This book makes me want to revisit my roots, and at the same time it makes me excited and apprehensive for what is soon to come. As immersive as the OASIS hardware that dominates every page, Cline pulls you into the digital environment he so wonderfully illustrates. A must read for anyone who has played games from the 80s onward. Don't pass this one up!

Ready player one creates a believable world with fun quirky characters. Actually found myself caring what happened to them. As other reviewers have pointed out the book is filled with trivia.  What I liked was that there's enough non-80's trivia so you don't feel left out if you don't catch all the 80's references. Should warn you that reading may result in craving for 80's era gaming.

Fantastic! 1980s babies are going to have so much fun with this read. With the audio book, Wil Wheaton is an awesome narrator and trust him with any audio books in the future. For those that love struggling youths in a dystopian future plugged into an MMORPG will enjoy this book. This is up there for me with the Hunger Games Trilogy, Ender's Game, Ender's Shadow, and Lord of the Flies.

Clever, hilarious, and unabashedly in love with the 80's and all it involved - pop culture, music, technology and videogames - this book is a treasure and a gem.  If you have even the slightest interest in, or fond memories of that decade that was the 1980s, especially where videogames are concerned, you will treasure this and ask your friends to read it, too.  I have my quarter ready.

I picked up this book to read over the weekend. I started and didn't want to put it down. I read it straight through. It is a rousing good tale. As a gamer, geek and nerd who grew up in those same years the book talks about, I loved every single page. I would heartily like to thank Ernest Cline for putting a smile on my face that lasted from cover to cover and even after I put it down.

I would give this book all of the stars. It's just so well done and all the characters are so well fleshed out. It's structurally flawless as a story as well. I actually don't really like first-person narratives, or coming-of-age stories all that much, but for this book I didn't care. Even though it was a tad formulaic at times, I didn't care. It was just so well done and so much fun.

The world in this book is every geek's wildest dream and worst nightmare rolled into one giant love letter to 80's pop culture. I loved nearly every moment in this book. It gets a bit wobbly in the middle with a romantic distraction from the ongoing plot, but it's brief and gets back on track fairly quickly. Other than that, it's an absolutely fantastic book and I highly recommend it.

All the elements of a great and fast-paced read present themselves in this Science Fiction tale, soon to become a classic. Creative, prophetic, and absorbing, Cline's novel is this generation's "Ender's Game." A young man teams with others to complete a quest that will affect the outcome of a failing global society. If you read anything this summer, you should read this book.

Original, detailed, well-written and orchestrated, the exuberant fun of this story is very engaging and a great ride. It might seem kind of lightweight to sophisticated readers, however once you take a close look at just how tightly-knit and well- researched the book is, you can appreciate the diligence and loving attention the author has passionately devoted to this rollicking tale.

This book constantly made me grin and laugh.  Growing up in the 70s and 80s, and having watched, read and played many of the items referenced in the book, I was constantly smiling as I read.  This book brought back so many good memories of being a kid.  I don't know if it will be as enjoyable to someone who can't relate to the period and culture, but for me it was just fantastic fun.

This book is brilliant! It almost feels like this book was written as a biography. Like Percival came back from the future to let us know how things are gonna turn out. I can't say enough good things about this book. I loved it. I feel this book is the 1984 of our time. Only we can see our technology evolving in this direction. I can see this being the best book I'll read this year.

This was the bees book I've read in a good while.  The pacing, action and plot are all great, but the true excellence is Clines tangible materialization on the culture of my youth and of the resulting gamer culture today.  The best settings and characters can't match a solid ether of point of view that makes a book come alive.  Like the gunters I must now crash far past my bed time.

This book delved a little too deeply into 80's nostalgia for my taste. I also felt like a lot of the book was very slow. The action sequences were fun, and once the actual puzzle solving started (about 25% of the way in) the pace picked up. Some of the scenes were very memorable too. Overall, I wouldn't recommend this book to another adult, but bet it would be great for the YA set.

I curse the author of this book! I picked it for a little light reading every now and then. Um, noooooo....cause I could not put it down. I take that back. I would stop. But only to look up movies, songs and bit of pop culture from the 1980's that I had not thought about in years. I will forgo listing plot details. It's better not to know. Just read it. You won't be sorry you did.

I was pleasantly surprised by this novel. It was a quick  read and held my interest like any great page-turner. I love how Cline beautifully mixed the modern with the nostalgic. It was really neat to see how he would integrate 80's pop culture. It's a most read if you love sci fi/fantasy movies, video games and just plain awesomeness. Do yourself a favor and jump for this novel.

If you're from the 80s (like I am) and you're a gamer geek (like I am) or if you like the 80s (like you all should because it was awesome) you're going to love this book.  I read about 75+ books a year (see geek comment) and this is by far the best book I've read in a couple of years.  It's a real page turner with an excellent method of story telling.  I'd highly recommend it!!

Amazing book, i dint want it to end. I have the audible version narrated by Will Wheaton ans is great. once i started listening to it I couldn't drop it. I expend the past 10 listening to the book with no brakes. It grabs you and wont let go, extremely engaging. Only wish it was longer and the end should have included more detail about the future of the protagonist. Loved it.

Was pleasantly shocked. As a "kid" of the 80's, this book kept taking me back to my childhood, while keeping my mind guessing on what trivia would be utilized next. Eventually I was able to see the standard story pattern, but it was enjoyable. So enjoyable, that I actually read it in one night and didn't sleep. It has been a long time since a book has done this for me.

This is a ridiculously fun ride through a disturbingly plausible view of the very near future, but packed from end to end with pop culture references that will be near and dear to anyone who grew up in the 80s. I absolutely loved this book and am only disappointed that it couldn't be longer. It's rare that I enjoy a book so much I don't want it to end. This is one of the few.

I happened upon this book while waiting in an office for an appointment.  I read the jacket and the first chapter and decided I needed to read this.  I couldn't put it down!  Being a kid from the 80's, every mention and music reference made me smile.  I completed the book in about 2 weeks and passed to a friend whom I asked to continue passing on.  Excellent and easy read!!!

Well, it's been a fun read. Lots of classic 80s cultural references, plot twists and thoughtful dialogs. The whole premise is cheesy at its best — a hero is born through adventures and perils, finds treasure and a princess at the end. But hey, that's the point. What's better that such an awesome hommage to the era of early videogames, hairy men in jumpsuits and weird music!

I hadn't really heard about this book before but bought it based on the good reviews.  I'm surprised it didn't get 5 stars.  I was very presently surprised that I found this gem.  If you are a sci-fi guy and are around 40 years old, this is really a must read.  It has so many references to a teenager's life in the 1980's as well as many other sci-fi and fantasy references.

Ernest Cline delivers in a big way with Ready Player One.  It's a book that I believe geeks and non-geeks can enjoy.  It's a fun and fanastic adventure filled with pop culture references, social commentary and a tales of love and friendship that anyone can relate to.  I read a lot of sci-fi and I think this and Wool by Hugh Howey are the top two I've read so far this year.

Fantastic book that took me back to a great time..  The 80's!  This book his a quick read because you won't put it down.  Nerds everywhere rejoice in a book you can share with your 12 year old son/daughter and have endless conversations, answer so many questions about the tech from your generation and also daydream with them in a future like it is set.  Worth every penny!

I was a teen in the 80s, and I'm definitely geeky.  And while I hung out with gamers, I never got into gaming myself.  Still - I'm in absolute love with this book. All the 80s references are fun and the gaming references are easy to follow, even for a non-gamer.  Give this a try - you won't be sorry.

A fun quick read but nothing revolutionary. Was really excited at first by the description of the dystopian world he described, but the story really doesn't go into it. Tries really hard to appeal to the target audience (a bit too much). No character development, and predictable storyline. Sometimes that's want you want though. It's like a geek action movie in book form.

Ready Player One is a novel I especially like to recommend to middle and high school students who think they don't like to read. That said I am a senior reader and I loved this book and didn't want it to end. It would be a great vacation read as well, it's just a ton of fun while also managing to have something very profound to say about our modern western civilization .

I think John Scalzi called this book a "nerdgasm", and I really couldn't put it any better.  This book managed both to let me revel in my own 1980's trivia geekdom, while at the same time telling a great science fiction story.  I almost couldn't put it down, and I've recommended it to pretty much everybody older than 30.  Even my wife liked it.  You should get this book!

I am a huge fan of the 80's, Cline and I were born in the same year and seem to share many similar interests.  I couldn't put Ready Player One down, but the authors references to 80's memorabilia and culture is bordering on indulgent.  Thus the 4 stars.  I could easily see this as a movie, however. Definitely recommended if you are remotely into 80's computing and music!

I loved it! If you are into the culture of the eighties and into video gaming, this book will captivate you! Almost every character reminded me of someone I knew or a public figure that I've read about! There's a surprising view of what can happen in a mostly virtual world and it will keep you thinking for quite a while. I can't wait for the next book from Ernest Cline!

Loved it. Really hope whoever makes this into a movie can do it justice. Personally, I would love to see it get made into three two hour episodes on HBO. Be a little miniseries. Maybe that's too much, but at least four hours. I just feel like this story was too big for an hour and a half to two hours. Anyway, loved the book, curious to see where he goes with the sequel.

Epic 80's geek culture romp told from a bleak future. I'm recommending this book to anyone that will listen. This deserves a place in my own personal library along side Harry Potter and Jurassic Park! If you are a geek that grow up in the late 70, entire 80's, or the early 90's then you will seriously dig this read. Why are you still reading this? Go read get this book!

This book was very engaging with some really cool 80's references. Thanks to the book I ended up watching some really good movies I had missed from that decade . This is also a very good dystopian novel and scarily closer to home than other dystopian novels I have read. Where it lacks depth it makes up for it with edge-of-the-seat story line. Totally worth each penny .

This book takes place in the dystopian future of 2044.  Life sucks for almost everybody, and their only escape is the OASIS.  The OASIS is a virtual reality world way more advanced than anything we have now.  Our narrator and hero is Wade Watts aka Parzival, a teenage geek.  No need for me to say more.  This is a great book if you are someone who grew up in the 1980's.

This book rocks. You can pretty much read the summaries above and a handful of reviews and you'll know whether or not you'll love this book. I forget where I heard about it but once I read that the author, Ernest Cline, loved Rush and a ton of other 80's pop culture staples that I did as well, I had to read this. And I TOTALLY LOVED every minute of it. Great, fun read!

If you remember the 80's, have ever played a MMORPG or just like pop culture in general you'll like this book. I couldn't put it down. So interesting and a throwback to so many things I remember as a kid. The cover said something like a mix of Willy Wonka and the Matrix and I think that describes it perfectly. I mean it, check this book out, you are going to love it!!

A friend of mine told me this was a good book and he was 100% correct. It brought back so many memories of growing up in the 70's and 80's, it was a step back into youth. I hope I read correctly about a movie... because the entire time I was reading this that was all I could think about. If you are a gamer from the 70's/80's this is definitely a book you want to read.

This is my favorite book so far this year!  I really liked this and highly recommend.  Once I got a few chapters in I couldn't put it down.  There are lots of pop coulter references that anyone who grew up in the 80s would probably really enjoy.  I thought this was entertaining and brings out your inner nerd.  Bottom line--this is a good book and I would recommend it!

I read this book cover to cover in one sitting- I literally couldn't put it down. The story is interesting, the book is well paced, and the characterizations are excellent. The whole thing is held together by a wonderful set of anecdotes, inside jokes, and 80's pop culture references that will make most folks who lived through the era smile with nostalgia. Great read!

I bought this book based on the number of reviews it garnered. I am glad to say that the majority is right. This book is outstanding. The whole premise just sucks you in: a treasure hunt in a Matrix-like game that references almost everything in 80's pop culture. I was sold from paragraph three onward when it quotes Ghostbusters. Buy this book; it doesn't disappoint.

A great cyber-adventure. The focus on 80s pop culture gets around the trouble of referencing things the reader can understand, when a novel is set in the future; however, sometimes it seems a little bit like the author was only writing the book to spite someone who said there was no use for knowing how to get a perfect score in PacMan. It was a very fun read though.

Any child of the 70s or 80s will love it. Bonus points if you're a gamer. Extra high marks of you're a reader. DVD bonuses if you're a TV addict. This loving homage to pop culture and nerdery has something for everyone. Except maybe for the jocks and cheerleaders, but really, you had your 15 minutes back in high school, so close enough to make no difference, eh wot?

Ernest Cline has written a great page turner and put an updated spin on the dreary futuristic, we all screw up the planet and now have a miserable life (except for this one all-encompassing / addictive thing) story line.  Mixing this dreary futuristic vision with 1980s nostalgia in a virtual environment is brilliant and kept my attention.  Well done sir, well done.

This is really teen fiction for anyone who was a teenager in the eighties. I had no problem mentally regressing and just enjoying the yarn. Sure, a few of the references went right over my head but I got enough of them to keep me entertained by both the story and my own flashbacks. Really good clean retrospective fun. I'd recommend it to anyone born in the sixties.

This book was, spectacular. The inclusion of 60-80s culture and video game lore appealed to me as an avid pc gamer but also a love of sci-fi novels. This book was extremely fluid and well written will a plot that was obviously lovingly made and well thought through. In my opinion the plot was sensational and I would recommend this book to all, video game fan or not

Highly recommended for all geeks, nerds and gamers, especially those who love the 80s!  That said, even if you are none of these things this just a ripping good yarn. I listened to the Will Wheaton read audiobook on a long trip and was actually disappointed when I got home 2 hours before the end. Bought the e-book  to finish it up. Thoroughly enjoyed both versions.

With such glowing reviews of this book it seems silly to wirte yet another one.  What can I say this book is great!  The idea is refreshing and new.  Just when you think all the ideas have been done to death in sci-fi along comes a book like this one.  I wont spoil the plot or the characters with a detailed explaination, but rather say this is well worth the read.

An amazing novel for both our current generation and those to come. For the Generation Xers who have children and for those children (like mine) who have never known a time when we didn't have computers and the Internet. It is one of those books you never forget. I will carry it with me in that virtual inventory like the egg that it is. Cudos to Ernie. Great job.

I read this as part of my work book club, and it was awesome! Were you a kid in the 80s? Then you'll love this. If you weren't, you still might enjoy it : )  It reads like an 80s movie, with all the adventure and whimsy you would expect, along with some of the slightly-too-convenient-to-be-true-isms mixed in for good measure. It's a fast read, but very enjoyable.

Great concept! It's the Willy Wonka story idea, but instead of a Chocolate Factory, it's a highly advanced  Virtual Reality/MMO/Internet environment that has the whole world captivated (far more so than our current internet) in which Gamers vie for the Golden Ticket (or Key in this case) and the narrative is engaging, the characters sympathetic and believable.

The story drags a little, and it somewhat predictable, but this is a fun read. I do have some complaints about the writing, as the author used some phrases over and over to the point of annoyance. The "internet speak" was a little hard to handle as well, as it was a little overblown. It's a decent sci-fi story, but not something particularly memorable.

My boyfriend and I decided to start a book club with each other, just the both of us, and I'm glad to say this is the book we started with. The detail of the future world allowed and challenged my imagination to soar. Great storyline, great characters, and again amazing scenery description. Highly suggest for sci-fi lovers and given a well deserved five stars.

Incredible book. I can hardly believe it is Cline's first novel. Well written, great flow, great character development. All the lore and references inspire me to delve back into my own nerd tendencies 100 fold. Highly recommended for anyone who appreciates video games, music, movies or television from the 80s, or just dystopian sci-fi. The genre at its finest.

Just discovered this book and it's very quickly become one of my favorite books of all time. It's as if Ernest Cline had been my best friend growing up, and wrote down every detail of my life and vowed to work them all into a novel someday. Loved every minute of it, and was a bit sad when the story ended (which happened quickly because I couldn't put it down)!
